My sense is that you'll see a very rapid adoption in consumer, as you've seen before, and enterprise will convert typically starting with the first equivalent with the service pack release or after their fall cycles are done. So it tends to lag -- initial deployment tends to lag 6 months or so.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Covello, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Covello, Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Somewhat related to John Pitzer's question. Stacy, you had presented some slides at the Analyst Meeting that I think you said kind of hold on tax, one of our view on unit growth changes. And then you presented a very helpful responsiveness case study. Is
componenttext: Somewhat related to John Pitzer's question. Stacy, you had presented some slides at the Analyst Meeting that I think you said kind of hold on tax, one of our view on unit growth changes. And then you presented a very helpful responsiveness case study. Is what you described to John relative to ramping down some older products and fabs and putting newer products in that and being at the low on the CapEx, is that the responsiveness case study or would that be another step altogether?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, it all falls under that general category of responding to changes in the demand environment. We're constantly looking at demand. And I realize we're -- CapEx, it's more important that we figure out what '13 and '14 demand looks like, but yes, as we se
componenttext: No, it all falls under that general category of responding to changes in the demand environment. We're constantly looking at demand. And I realize we're -- CapEx, it's more important that we figure out what '13 and '14 demand looks like, but yes, as we see opportunities to take 32-nanometer capacity off-line and roll it forward, then it offsets capital that we would've had to buy for 22 nanometer. The case study I showed was one where you see a dramatic shift in demand levels that happens as a result of a financial crisis that takes everything down in a very fast period of time. This is when our expectations are just moderating and so we're finding some incremental opportunities to start to react that way.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: And so I guess as my follow-up, I mean, do -- what do you think about factory loadings or utilization as you go through the third quarter as your outlook for the year changes and some of the capacity from the previously spent CapEx kind of ramps up? You t
componenttext: And so I guess as my follow-up, I mean, do -- what do you think about factory loadings or utilization as you go through the third quarter as your outlook for the year changes and some of the capacity from the previously spent CapEx kind of ramps up? You think the factory loadings will remain at the high level, utilization stays at the same level or do you -- do we begin to bring that down some?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: At 22 nanometers, so the process where we're doing Ivy Bridge, that'll stay full. We see the demand signals continue to be strong and we're going through the inventory replenishment to get the freshest stuff into inventory. We have seen loadings come down
componenttext: At 22 nanometers, so the process where we're doing Ivy Bridge, that'll stay full. We see the demand signals continue to be strong and we're going through the inventory replenishment to get the freshest stuff into inventory. We have seen loadings come down some in 32 nanometer, not to the point that we're taking underload charges but to the point that we can start to take a little bit of that capacity off-line. And as I said to John's question, if I have to brand to predict, I think we'll find more of those opportunities over the course of the back half of this year.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Craig Ellis, Caris & Company.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Craig Ellis, Caris & Company.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Paul, just back on the Ultrabook topic. As you look into the back half of the year, how do you see the Ultrabook mix shaking out as a percent of notebooks? I think in the past, you've referenced a 40% of consumer notebooks by the end of this year. Is that
componenttext: Paul, just back on the Ultrabook topic. As you look into the back half of the year, how do you see the Ultrabook mix shaking out as a percent of notebooks? I think in the past, you've referenced a 40% of consumer notebooks by the end of this year. Is that still a reasonable number or how are you looking at that?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. We really haven't changed our view on that. A couple of things give us confidence there. One is the first half shipments on Ultrabooks. We're essentially right on our expectation set over 6 months ago. And the design pipeline for what we see i
componenttext: Yes, it is. We really haven't changed our view on that. A couple of things give us confidence there. One is the first half shipments on Ultrabooks. We're essentially right on our expectation set over 6 months ago. And the design pipeline for what we see in the second half and the price points that we see, we think, will get us there. In a softer selling season, I think these machines become even more attractive. And so -- so they may -- they -- I'm fairly confident we'll hit our volume goals with this in terms of the percent mix for the consumer notebooks.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then switching gears, Stacy, you had mentioned in earlier commentary you'd come back to the NAND business side. I don't think I heard you do that, so I just thought I'd give you the opportunity to make any comment that you might have.
componenttext: Great. And then switching gears, Stacy, you had mentioned in earlier commentary you'd come back to the NAND business side. I don't think I heard you do that, so I just thought I'd give you the opportunity to make any comment that you might have.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was assuming someone was going to ask me the question. Yes, I -- we saw NAND soft in Q2. You saw on our commentary and as Paul alluded to. I don't think it's just us. I think you're seeing that from other companies. It's led to us being a little lower i
componenttext: I was assuming someone was going to ask me the question. Yes, I -- we saw NAND soft in Q2. You saw on our commentary and as Paul alluded to. I don't think it's just us. I think you're seeing that from other companies. It's led to us being a little lower in revenue. I think that continues as part of the lowering of expectations into the back half. There's a chunk of that that's NAND-related. I want to contrast it, though, it's really different compared to the last downturn we went through, which I think was about 4 years ago. You really see the impact of the strategy that we've been pursuing in that business. The fact that we now have process technology leadership and we've transitioned all of our shipments to higher-margin segments of the NAND market like [ph] SSDs and compute-NAND. So that even though while it's impacting us at the top line, it's a business that still is generating positive profit and it's still generating positive cash flow. As a fairly new CFO when the last big downturn hit NAND and it was quite different because we didn't have that cost leadership and we were shipping into the commodity segments of the business. So I think it's a real testament to what they have accomplished in the business, but it's definitely soft.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, all, for joining us today. Hope, please go ahead and wrap up the call.
componenttext: All right. Thank you, all, for joining us today. Hope, please go ahead and wrap up the call.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Hope, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Intel second quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Mark Henninger, Director of Investor Relations,
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Hope, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Intel second quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Mark Henninger, Director of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hope, and welcome, everyone, to Intel's Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. By now, you should have received a copy of our earnings release and the CFO commentary that goes along with that. If you've not received both documents, they'
componenttext:
Thank you, Hope, and welcome, everyone, to Intel's Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. By now, you should have received a copy of our earnings release and the CFO commentary that goes along with that. If you've not received both documents, they're currently available on our investor website, www.intc.com. I'm joined today by Paul Otellini, our President and CEO; and Stacy Smith, our Chief Financial Officer.
In a moment, we'll hear brief remarks from both of them followed by Q&A.
Before we begin, let me remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements based on the environment as we currently see it, and as such, does include risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our press release for more information on the specific risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially. Also if during this call we use any non-GAAP financial measures or references, we'll post the appropriate GAAP financial reconciliations to our website, intc.com. So with that, let me hand it over to Paul.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Against a backdrop of mixed macroeconomic trends, our business in the second quarter played out largely as we expected. We continue to enjoy a rich mix of products in both the PC and Data Center Group, and our d
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Against a backdrop of mixed macroeconomic trends, our business in the second quarter played out largely as we expected. We continue to enjoy a rich mix of products in both the PC and Data Center Group, and our distributor channel had its best Q2 in 5 years.
Our Technology and Manufacturing Group, once again, delivered fantastic results. Our 22-nanometer process help [ph] is ahead of where 32 nanometers was at the same point in its ramp and ahead of our own plans. That enabled us to ramp Ivy Bridge to nearly 1/4 of our PC volume, our fastest ramp ever. We also announced an important agreement with ASML last week that we expect will accelerate the developments and deployment of 450-millimeter and EUV lithography technologies by up to 2 years and deliver significant value to our shareholders.
Ultrabooks continued to build momentum and achieved our volume goals for the first half. We are very pleased with the level of innovation and invention being brought into this category and are now tracking over 140 Ivy Bridge-based designs in the pipeline. Of those, more than 40 will be touch-enabled and a dozen will be convertibles. With visibility into this many designs, we are very confident that we'll see $699 systems at retail this fall. We are also tracking more than 20 Windows 8 tablet designs based on our low-power and low-cost Clover Trail Atom SoC in addition to a number of core-based tablets. 
In our Data Center business, volume growth combined with a rich mix drove record server revenues. In fact, the mix of 2 of our highest-performing Romley products was more than 2x that of the prior generation Westmere at the same point in its ramp. DCG grew 15% over the second quarter last year, with cloud volume growing at more than twice the rate of the rest of the server market segment. Those figures put the Data Center on track to the growth targets that we shared with you in May.
High-performance computing continues to be one of the fastest-growing segments within our Data Center business. And earlier this quarter, we announced more technical details behind our new Many Integrated Core coprocessor due out later this year. Branded Xeon Phi, this new product family will combine the throughput of highly parallel computing with the familiar programming models of the Intel architecture. Phi will be an impressive product for the HPC market segment with more than 50 cores, manufactured on our 22-nanometer tri-gate process technology. We already have more than 40 customers signed up to support the architecture.
In the smartphone space, we saw the launch of Medfield-based phones from Lenovo, Lava and Orange to great reviews. These launches further established Intel in the market, building on the wide presence we have in base spends.
Overall, our business in the first half was consistent with our expectations. As we look ahead to the second half of the year, consumer market growth in Western Europe and North America is not forecasted to recover as fast as we had anticipated. 
Worldwide enterprise demand is growing as expected. Emerging markets, especially China and Brazil, are still growing nicely, but are moderating due to GDP adjustments and currency fluctuations. Taken together, these factors have led us to adjust our expectations for the second half. We are now expecting full year revenue growth in the 3% to 5% range versus our prior expectation of high-single digits. Our results in the second quarter demonstrate that having a deep and long-established presence in every geography, combined with leading technology, manufacturing and products are important in any environment. But they are especially valuable in the mixed market we are now experiencing. 
With a wide range of Ultrabooks and Intel-based tablets expected to be available this year and an exciting Windows 8 launch just around the corner, we remain optimistic about our future. With that, let me turn the call over to Stacy.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. The second quarter results came in largely as expected. Second quarter revenue came in at $13.5 billion, up 4% year-on-year. Enterprise and emerging markets contributed to the year-on-year growth, somewhat offset by continued weakness in mat
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. The second quarter results came in largely as expected. Second quarter revenue came in at $13.5 billion, up 4% year-on-year. Enterprise and emerging markets contributed to the year-on-year growth, somewhat offset by continued weakness in mature markets. The core business came in as expected, but we saw softness in our NAND memory business. At a segment level, the PC Group grew 4% from a year ago and the Data Center Group grew 15%.
Inventory levels across the worldwide PC supply chain are healthy but are being managed below historical averages based on macroeconomic uncertainty and ahead of the Windows 8 operating system release. For the third quarter of 2012, we are forecasting the midpoint of the revenue range at $14.3 billion, up 6% from the second quarter, which is at the lower end of the historical range.
Moving to gross margin. Second quarter gross margin of 63% was slightly better than the midpoint of our guidance and down slightly from the first quarter. Our forecast for 2012 is unchanged at 64% gross margin for the year, and our gross margin forecast for the third quarter is 63%.
As expected, the fast ramp of Ivy Bridge resulted in a cost increase in the second quarter. We expected the second quarter was the peak in terms of platform unit cost, with costs coming down in the third quarter and more in the fourth quarter.
For the second quarter, spending was in line with expectations at $4.6 billion. Based on the macroeconomic environment, we have taken actions to slow hiring, and as a result, are lowering our spending forecast for the year to $18.2 billion. We expect spending in the third and fourth quarters to be flat to the second quarter. 
Taking a look at the balance sheet, total cash investments ended the quarter at $13.6 billion, approximately flat to the first quarter. We generated approximately $5 billion in cash from operations, paid approximately $1 billion in dividends, purchased nearly $3 billion in capital assets and had roughly $1 billion of stock repurchases. Inventory grew by approximately $400 million. More than all of the increase in inventories came from the Ivy Bridge ramp with an offset as we reduced inventory levels of older generation products.
While macroeconomic weakness and our expectation that our customers will continue to maintain lower inventory levels has led us to reduce our expectations to 3% to 5% revenue growth for the year, we continue to make great progress in the market. Both Romley and Ivy Bridge ramps are significantly faster than their predecessors. We are winning significant designs in Ultrabooks, phones and tablets. And our manufacturing lead continues to generate leading products and low costs. With that, let me turn it back over to Mark.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Paul and Stacy. We'll now move on to the Q&A. [Operator Instructions] Hope, would you please go ahead and introduce our first questioner.
componenttext: All right. Thank you, Paul and Stacy. We'll now move on to the Q&A. [Operator Instructions] Hope, would you please go ahead and introduce our first questioner.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: So our first question comes from the line of Glen Yeung, Citi.
componenttext: So our first question comes from the line of Glen Yeung, Citi.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question is about the distributors. I think, Paul, you said that they had their best Q2 in 5 years. And I wonder if you could just explain the reasons why that's the case.
componenttext: I guess my first question is about the distributors. I think, Paul, you said that they had their best Q2 in 5 years. And I wonder if you could just explain the reasons why that's the case.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, over the -- I think it's been -- yes, best Q2 in 5 years. Over the last several years, our distribution channel role has shifted and evolved quite a bit. If you take a snapshot 5 years ago, most of the business was them distributing desktop micropro
componenttext: Well, over the -- I think it's been -- yes, best Q2 in 5 years. Over the last several years, our distribution channel role has shifted and evolved quite a bit. If you take a snapshot 5 years ago, most of the business was them distributing desktop microprocessors and motherboards then went into white box builds. And as the PC market shifted from desktops to notebooks, they became less of a driver of the PC volume. They picked up skill sets to do systems integration and they're now among our larger server channels. So the distribution channel has sort of reinvented itself and is now a fairly significant force in not just the desktops in emerging markets or preassembled notebooks but increasingly for servers and storage systems.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as a follow-up, maybe for Stacy, looking at the gross margin guidance and looking at your reconciliation in the printed commentary, it sounded like the only negative impact to gross margins in Q3 would be these other cost of sales. And I wonde
componenttext: Got it. And as a follow-up, maybe for Stacy, looking at the gross margin guidance and looking at your reconciliation in the printed commentary, it sounded like the only negative impact to gross margins in Q3 would be these other cost of sales. And I wonder if you could just explain what's going on in there.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. The -- what's going on with other cost of sales in Q3 is we're finding some opportunities to take some 32-nanometer capacity off-line. They are relatively small today, but it's just a result of the lower demand expectations on the year. And so we're
componenttext: Sure. The -- what's going on with other cost of sales in Q3 is we're finding some opportunities to take some 32-nanometer capacity off-line. They are relatively small today, but it's just a result of the lower demand expectations on the year. And so we're taking some of those factories off, and so you'll see a little bit of demolition costs and some of those things that flows through other cost of sales. And it's not huge, it's between 0.5 point and a point, but it's a bit of an offset in gross margin in the third quarter.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Is it temporary or it just happens once and then it doesn't recur?
componenttext: Is it temporary or it just happens once and then it doesn't recur?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. Again, you've seen us do this before, Glen, when we have demand coming in less than expected and I actually talked about it in the investor meeting. We look for the opportunities to take the older generation capacity off-line, and because
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. Again, you've seen us do this before, Glen, when we have demand coming in less than expected and I actually talked about it in the investor meeting. We look for the opportunities to take the older generation capacity off-line, and because we can reuse that equipment at the leading edge, we just take advantage of those opportunities.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sumit Dhanda, ISI Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sumit Dhanda, ISI Group.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: First question, Stacy, could you just tell us in terms of your expectations on the channel refill that you talked about on the previous call. Are you shipping back to demand levels? Does that 3% rise in PC client units reflect that or was that below your
componenttext: First question, Stacy, could you just tell us in terms of your expectations on the channel refill that you talked about on the previous call. Are you shipping back to demand levels? Does that 3% rise in PC client units reflect that or was that below your expectations? And how exactly are you thinking about that into the third quarter?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, so generally in the second quarter, the core business came in as we expected when we started the quarter, the -- being slightly below the midpoint was really entirely due to NAND, which I can talk about separately later in the call. In terms of what
componenttext: Yes, so generally in the second quarter, the core business came in as we expected when we started the quarter, the -- being slightly below the midpoint was really entirely due to NAND, which I can talk about separately later in the call. In terms of what our expectations of the inventory pipeline, I think we saw more in Q2 than we expected. And as we look into the back half of the year, our current expectation, based on what we're hearing from customers, is based on macroeconomic uncertainty and the timing of the Windows 8 launch. They're going to continue to manage inventory levels. We -- and that's a change from where we were a quarter ago and really points to the below seasonal guide for the third quarter.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as my follow-up, just a question on the -- what seems to be a pretty significant dichotomy between notebook volumes and desktop volumes sequentially, especially given that you said enterprise was decent so I would have thought desktops migh
componenttext: Okay. And then as my follow-up, just a question on the -- what seems to be a pretty significant dichotomy between notebook volumes and desktop volumes sequentially, especially given that you said enterprise was decent so I would have thought desktops might do a little better. But curious to hear what the explanation on that is, if any.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's not new. We've been seeing robust notebook growth rates now for several years, well in excess of what's happening in desktop. I'd say notebooks, really, is a volume story, and then in desktops, I think what they've done a really good job of is drivin
componenttext: It's not new. We've been seeing robust notebook growth rates now for several years, well in excess of what's happening in desktop. I'd say notebooks, really, is a volume story, and then in desktops, I think what they've done a really good job of is driving segmentation. And so again, even with lower unit growth, they've been driving some nice revenue growth, but a lot is segmentation and ASP uplift.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Berenbaum, MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Berenbaum, MKM Partners.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: So maybe I should just follow up on that. When you talk about segmentation and ASP uplift, that also leads into the competitive scenario question. Obviously, you're doing a lot better than your primary competitor just based on their recent news. Can you t
componenttext: So maybe I should just follow up on that. When you talk about segmentation and ASP uplift, that also leads into the competitive scenario question. Obviously, you're doing a lot better than your primary competitor just based on their recent news. Can you talk a little bit about why you think that is in the PC space? You mentioned a little bit that emerging markets are still growing well from you. Do you think it's competition in the emerging markets or is it more related to Data Center? Can you help us understand that?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- if I understand their preannouncement, what we did a little bit better than we thought this quarter was probably in the low-end desktop and notebook business, where we probably took back a little share at the bottom of the PC SKUs. I don't --
componenttext: Well, the -- if I understand their preannouncement, what we did a little bit better than we thought this quarter was probably in the low-end desktop and notebook business, where we probably took back a little share at the bottom of the PC SKUs. I don't -- I think our position in servers is really unchanged and is really quite good.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then going back to the inventory question, you talked about inventory in the channel being a bit low, but your own inventory is quite high. Understand a lot of this is coming from the ramp of the new products. But what gives you the confidence i
componenttext: Okay. And then going back to the inventory question, you talked about inventory in the channel being a bit low, but your own inventory is quite high. Understand a lot of this is coming from the ramp of the new products. But what gives you the confidence in guiding to relatively high gross margins for the rest of the year? And for the full year, are you -- what are the puts-and-takes there and what should we be concerned about or what are you concerned about potentially with that inventory build?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me take those as 2 separate things. The inventory build is directionally what we expected. I think the one thing that we're doing is we're able to fill Ivy Bridge a little faster than we thought, and Ivy Bridge is -- it counts for all of the i
componenttext: Yes. So let me take those as 2 separate things. The inventory build is directionally what we expected. I think the one thing that we're doing is we're able to fill Ivy Bridge a little faster than we thought, and Ivy Bridge is -- it counts for all of the inventory growth. It's both units and dollars this quarter. And when I look across CPU inventory level, Ivy Bridge is now more than half of the inventory that's sitting in there. As I think about the next quarter, I think we'll be pretty flat and we'll see business levels start to grow, and so days of inventory will start coming down from here would be my expectation. The gross margin story for us really is a cost story, and I talked about this last quarter. We have this phenomenon where we'll ramp multiple factories at the same time on 22-nanometer. Those early products coming out of the factories are pretty expensive products. That led to a peaking cost in Q2. As we move into Q3, we now have the phenomenon where cost comes down rapidly on Ivy Bridge, but as Paul talked to you about, it's about 1/4 of our volume in Q2. We're going to more or less double that volume in Q3. And so this phenomenon where costs come down but the volume doubles, I'll see some cost good news in Q3, it's between 0.5 point and a point, and then I get more cost good news in Q4 as that ramp starts to flatten out a bit. And so really, the thing I'm watching on gross margin is are we on the path of cost reduction of Ivy Bridge? And on the ramp rate, we're doing great on the cost. The ramp rate's a little ahead of forecast. That gives me the confidence that we'll see a gross margin in Q4 that's kind of around 65%, and that gets me to 64% for the year.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Danely, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Danely, JPMorgan.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: First question for Paul. Paul, can you just talk about maybe put a little more color around the macro slowdown you're seeing, when it happened, was it just a sudden jump down? Is it in a slow erosion and maybe go into the geos a little bit, which has been
componenttext: First question for Paul. Paul, can you just talk about maybe put a little more color around the macro slowdown you're seeing, when it happened, was it just a sudden jump down? Is it in a slow erosion and maybe go into the geos a little bit, which has been more impacted or less impacted?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, let me color it by saying that we still see growth in all these geographies and we're forecasting a stronger second half than first half. And I gave you the year-over-year numbers. What we had expected that we would see by now is
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, let me color it by saying that we still see growth in all these geographies and we're forecasting a stronger second half than first half. And I gave you the year-over-year numbers. What we had expected that we would see by now is that the U.S. and Western Europe consumer businesses would be recovering from sort of a softness that we were seeing for several quarters. And as a result of not seeing that, 2 things are happening. One, we don't see the PC sales to be as robust as we first thought, but the inventory replenishment coming off of the hard drive shortage is not as deep as we thought or as large as we thought, because there are people expecting to sell into a smaller overall TAM growth. In terms of China and Brazil, which I singled out and -- but I could have also spoken a little bit about maybe Russia in that, and India, in some of the countries we're seeing the prices of computers go up as a result of the currency fluctuations against the dollar. Most PC components, including ours, are sold globally in dollars and the PCs are typically priced in dollars, so -- at least to the distributors in those countries, so the price goes up as the currency changes. In China, it's a little bit different. What we're seeing there is an abatement of the GDP growth, sort of 8%, 8.25% down to 7%, 7.25%. And while we still see growth there, we don't see quite as much as we first thought. So you add all those together plus the fact that the enterprise is doing pretty good, you come down to a more muted growth scenario than we first thought.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: And as my follow-up, it sounds like you're guiding Q4 to be somewhat back to normal. Is that because you expect Win 8 to drive PC demand or some inventory replenishment or will your tablet and handset efforts start to be material, can you just go into det
componenttext: And as my follow-up, it sounds like you're guiding Q4 to be somewhat back to normal. Is that because you expect Win 8 to drive PC demand or some inventory replenishment or will your tablet and handset efforts start to be material, can you just go into detail on that?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think if you take the -- Chris, if you take the midpoint of our revenue guidance for the year, you'll come out to a Q4 that's kind of seasonal on the back of a below seasonal Q3. So I'd say we're just -- it's a continuation of the trends that we've seen
componenttext: I think if you take the -- Chris, if you take the midpoint of our revenue guidance for the year, you'll come out to a Q4 that's kind of seasonal on the back of a below seasonal Q3. So I'd say we're just -- it's a continuation of the trends that we've seen. Specifically to your question, no, it's not predicated on boomer sales in either tablets or in smartphones. But don't take from that, that those aren't important segments. We think we're on a path to have a lot of products in the market. We're winning design wins, it's really the momentum that builds into 2013.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: So then why Q4 back to normal then?
componenttext: So then why Q4 back to normal then?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we would expect that we're going to leave Q3 with relatively lower inventory levels. You have a refresh with Windows. And we have seen over 20 years of history, a pattern that back-half sales tend to be larger than front-half sales. And so I think i
componenttext: Well, we would expect that we're going to leave Q3 with relatively lower inventory levels. You have a refresh with Windows. And we have seen over 20 years of history, a pattern that back-half sales tend to be larger than front-half sales. And so I think it's a reasonable baseline for customers.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Romit Shah, Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Romit Shah, Nomura.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: There have been reports over the last month or so that Intel's been cutting prices on hyperBridge. I was hoping you could just comment on that. Is it true? What's behind it?
componenttext: There have been reports over the last month or so that Intel's been cutting prices on hyperBridge. I was hoping you could just comment on that. Is it true? What's behind it?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. Our pricing strategy is unchanged and Ivy Bridge is coming in at the top of the scale. What those reports may -- I haven't seen the reports, Romit, but they may be just pointing to the fact that we're filling in more price points with Ivy Bridge, but
componenttext: No. Our pricing strategy is unchanged and Ivy Bridge is coming in at the top of the scale. What those reports may -- I haven't seen the reports, Romit, but they may be just pointing to the fact that we're filling in more price points with Ivy Bridge, but we have not reduced our price points. As Paul said, by the way, the place where we probably want some share and where we're seeing kind of robust pricing is more at the very low end of the PC market. It's not where Ivy Bridge is playing.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then Stacy, in your gross margin guidance for Q3, you highlighted lower platform ASPs. Could you give us some color there?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then Stacy, in your gross margin guidance for Q3, you highlighted lower platform ASPs. Could you give us some color there?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. In -- realize that we're talking kind of 0.5 point to a point, relatively small changes. But in the third quarter, there's a couple of things that has caused me to put that forecast up. First, Q3 tends to be a larger consumer quarter, so you see a li
componenttext: Yes. In -- realize that we're talking kind of 0.5 point to a point, relatively small changes. But in the third quarter, there's a couple of things that has caused me to put that forecast up. First, Q3 tends to be a larger consumer quarter, so you see a little bit of a mix impact associated with that. Again, not changing our price point, it's just the mix of what we think sells through in the third quarter. And then the second thing is what I was just talking about, we think we probably gained some share at the low end of the market. We'd expect that to continue into the third quarter but fairly muted impact. So all of this is in the context of what I articulated at the beginning of the year of a pretty benign pricing environment. I haven't seen anything that causes me to change that view.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Pitzer, Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Pitzer, Crédit Suisse.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Stacy, you guys are kind of controlling OpEx relative to a slightly weaker-than-expected demand environment. You've also talked about kind of doing what you did back in the financial crisis of moving some spare capacity forward, but you haven't changed th
componenttext: Stacy, you guys are kind of controlling OpEx relative to a slightly weaker-than-expected demand environment. You've also talked about kind of doing what you did back in the financial crisis of moving some spare capacity forward, but you haven't changed the overall CapEx number for the year. Is that because this is predominantly brick-and-mortar or does that give you more flexibility on next year's CapEx? If you could just help me understand that dynamic?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- so what we're spending CapEx on this year is really kind of building that 22-nanometer ramp. It's not peak 22-nanometer. And that capital is appropriate to invest really in any economic climate. So the change in the demand environment hasn't
componenttext: Well, the -- so what we're spending CapEx on this year is really kind of building that 22-nanometer ramp. It's not peak 22-nanometer. And that capital is appropriate to invest really in any economic climate. So the change in the demand environment hasn't changed our view of at least the 22-nanometer capital we're putting in place today. That said, as I'd said earlier, we are seeing some opportunities to take some older-generation capacity off-line and roll forward. My guess is as we work through those, we'll end up at the lower end of the range on CapEx. We're just -- we're working through those opportunities as we speak, and I think we'll come down a bit from here.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then, Paul, relative to the Win 8 launch, Microsoft has now come out and decided they want to be a tablet company with a surface product and it sounds like their intent is not to use that as a reference design for other orients to follow, but to actua
componenttext: And then, Paul, relative to the Win 8 launch, Microsoft has now come out and decided they want to be a tablet company with a surface product and it sounds like their intent is not to use that as a reference design for other orients to follow, but to actually try to make a real business out of that. What kind of impact do you think that might have on the traditional PC business, if any?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Boy, well, I think you're going to have to ask our customers that question. From our perspective, I guess we're certainly happy to have them as another hardware customer. We haven't sold chips to them for quite some time since the Xbox days. But in terms
componenttext: Boy, well, I think you're going to have to ask our customers that question. From our perspective, I guess we're certainly happy to have them as another hardware customer. We haven't sold chips to them for quite some time since the Xbox days. But in terms of the ecosystem, I don't know that we know their plans deeply enough in terms of this -- of light chip SKU or they tend to have broader designs on the market. I don't know. And so I think that question has to go to them and to our customers.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, your PC client ASPs are staying within the benign range that I think you had mentioned multiple times. I'm curious, is there some scope of benefit from becoming a little more aggressive on pricing to stimulate demand or is this a very price inelast
componenttext: First, your PC client ASPs are staying within the benign range that I think you had mentioned multiple times. I'm curious, is there some scope of benefit from becoming a little more aggressive on pricing to stimulate demand or is this a very price inelastic market? And where I'm going with that is on the Ultrabook side. Would it help to be somewhat more aggressive than -- because you do have cost leadership and flexibility?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think that the value associated with the Ultrabooks -- they start with the core product line, the Core i3, i5 and i7s -- is still pretty good. And I commented in my statement that I think that -- we're quite sure that the prices are go
componenttext: I don't think so. I think that the value associated with the Ultrabooks -- they start with the core product line, the Core i3, i5 and i7s -- is still pretty good. And I commented in my statement that I think that -- we're quite sure that the prices are going to be $699 in the sweet spot. If there was that kind of elasticity, which we have not seen, then I would expect some of the thin and light designs around the Pentium and Celeron chips that we sell would pick up some of that volume, and we don't see that today. What we're seeing is that in a time of tight consumer budgets, people buy quality and they tend to buy the high end of the line or reasonably high end of our product lines. So it's not going to last [ph]. If you want something to last a few years, and that tends to give them a bit more of assurance. And I'd also say the other thing that hasn't come up yet is the Win 7 to Win 8 transition. And as we have done in the past in terms of working with Microsoft, the units that are shipped now in the marketplace are Win 8-ready. And they have programs and set of programs to be able to buy the upgrade with a coupon at a deep discount.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: And for my follow-up, I think you had mentioned consumer weakness in the mature markets, mostly due to the macro. But I'm wondering, what role are tablets playing in that and how soon can we look to Clover Trail-based tablets to sort of help reverse that
componenttext: And for my follow-up, I think you had mentioned consumer weakness in the mature markets, mostly due to the macro. But I'm wondering, what role are tablets playing in that and how soon can we look to Clover Trail-based tablets to sort of help reverse that trend?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, certainly over the last couple of years, as tablet volumes have ramped up, they do present and they have presented an alternative for consumer share of wallet, particularly at a time when consumer share of wallet is tighter than it has been in
componenttext: Yes, well, certainly over the last couple of years, as tablet volumes have ramped up, they do present and they have presented an alternative for consumer share of wallet, particularly at a time when consumer share of wallet is tighter than it has been in the past. And our thesis really hasn't changed here, which is that these are incremental machines for the most part. People still have primary computers in their lives, most people do. Much like they did like what we saw when the netbooks ramped up several years ago. As Intel-based tablets start shipping, both on Windows 8 and Android, we expect to be able to participate in that fast-growing market. But I don't think those numbers are going to be material this year. I think that just because of the timing of the start, it's going to be a slower ramp. And Stacy really addressed that earlier in his comment on phones and tablets.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right. I'm just wondering why the ARM camp has been so much more aggressive after that Windows 8 tablet market and why Microsoft did not launch a Clover Trail-based -- or did not announce a Clover Trail-based tablet. It's just a -- is it just a differ
componenttext: All right. I'm just wondering why the ARM camp has been so much more aggressive after that Windows 8 tablet market and why Microsoft did not launch a Clover Trail-based -- or did not announce a Clover Trail-based tablet. It's just a -- is it just a difference of timing or...

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you need to -- they talk about a core-based machine that's more like an Ultrabook. It's a convertible kind of machine, which I think is actually a pretty good machine. It's a no-compromise device. So my -- certainly when I go shopping, that'
componenttext: Well, I think you need to -- they talk about a core-based machine that's more like an Ultrabook. It's a convertible kind of machine, which I think is actually a pretty good machine. It's a no-compromise device. So my -- certainly when I go shopping, that's the device I'd buy.

componenttext: Yes, I think the last quarter I said that unit growth was relatively muted and it was really cost. This quarter where it's units primarily and then cost is secondary. So I'm not going to get to that level of granularity, but you should kind of visualize this as we are -- our inventories -- we are reducing units on an older generation products and we're refilling our inventory pipeline with Ivy Bridge. That's primarily units of Ivy Bridge and then those units are a little bit more expensive still than the Sandy Bridge parts that they're replacing.

componenttext: Got it. And one last question here. On the Ultrabook side, I know you mentioned you expect pricing to go to $699. What are the dollars you see there, because just like SSD pricing, NAND pricing is kind of starting to stabilize there to the red zone.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, NAND pricing has not been stabilizing. I mean that's one of the reasons we didn't hit the midpoint this quarter. That was the reason. What we're seeing, though, is there's a variety of SKUs that our customers are designing. I talked about over 140 d
componenttext: Well, NAND pricing has not been stabilizing. I mean that's one of the reasons we didn't hit the midpoint this quarter. That was the reason. What we're seeing, though, is there's a variety of SKUs that our customers are designing. I talked about over 140 designs. Some of them are aiming at a premium segment and higher prices using SSDs. Some of them are using these ultra-low profile, very high-capacity drives, which are now becoming available, which gives you the capacity and the thinness at the same time, which I think is a nice way to hit lower price points.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Paul, a couple of questions on Windows 8. How much of the guide in Q3 is due to this potential air pocket in front of Windows 8? And how do you see Windows 8 next year in terms of traditional historical operating system cycles?
componenttext: Paul, a couple of questions on Windows 8. How much of the guide in Q3 is due to this potential air pocket in front of Windows 8? And how do you see Windows 8 next year in terms of traditional historical operating system cycles?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't know how much of the -- what was your phrase, air pocket, is Windows 8 versus the macroeconomics. In fact, it's very hard for us to distinguish that today given that we have not seen stalls before because -- we see -- we're shipping chips in to ou
componenttext: I don't know how much of the -- what was your phrase, air pocket, is Windows 8 versus the macroeconomics. In fact, it's very hard for us to distinguish that today given that we have not seen stalls before because -- we see -- we're shipping chips in to our customers in advance of the operating system being loaded. But having said that, since the last Windows release, we've moved to more of a hub model with our chips, so that means people can draw these a bit more just in time. So that may be some of the air pocket that we're seeing, to use your phrase, in Q3, but I think that gets filled up pretty quickly in Q4. And it's, as I said earlier, a lot of people buy the Win 7 machines with a coupon and then upgrade.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then for next year?
componenttext: Okay. And then for next year?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Too soon to say. My sense is that you'll see a very rapid adoption in consumer, as we've seen before, and enterprise will convert typically starting with the first equivalent with the service pack release or after their fall cycles are done. So it tends t
componenttext: Too soon to say. My sense is that you'll see a very rapid adoption in consumer, as we've seen before, and enterprise will convert typically starting with the first equivalent with the service pack release or after their fall cycles are done. So it tends to lag -- initial deployment tends to lag 6 months or so.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Somewhat related to John Pitzer's question. Stacy, you had presented some slides at the Analyst Meeting that I think you said kind of hold on techs, what if our view on unit growth changes. And then you presented a very helpful responsiveness case study.
componenttext: Somewhat related to John Pitzer's question. Stacy, you had presented some slides at the Analyst Meeting that I think you said kind of hold on techs, what if our view on unit growth changes. And then you presented a very helpful responsiveness case study. Is what you described to John relative to ramping down some older products and fabs and putting newer products in that and being at the low end of CapEx, is that the responsiveness case study or would that be another step altogether?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, it all falls under that general category of responding to changes in the demand environment. We're constantly looking at demand. And I realize we're -- CapEx, it's more important that we figure out what '13 and '14 demand looks like, but yes, as we se
componenttext: No, it all falls under that general category of responding to changes in the demand environment. We're constantly looking at demand. And I realize we're -- CapEx, it's more important that we figure out what '13 and '14 demand looks like, but yes, as we see opportunities to take 32-nanometer capacity off-line and roll it forward, then it offsets capital that we would have had to buy for 22 nanometer. The case study I showed was one where you see a dramatic shift in demand levels that happens as a result of a financial crisis that takes everything down in a very fast period of time. This is when our expectations are just moderating and so we're finding some incremental opportunities to start to react that way.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: And so I guess as my follow-up, I mean, do -- what do you think about factory loadings or utilization as you go through the third quarter as your outlook for the year changes and some of the capacity from the previously spent CapEx kind of ramps up? You t
componenttext: And so I guess as my follow-up, I mean, do -- what do you think about factory loadings or utilization as you go through the third quarter as your outlook for the year changes and some of the capacity from the previously spent CapEx kind of ramps up? You think the factory loadings will remain at a high level, utilization stays at the same level or do you -- do we begin to bring that down some?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: At 22 nanometers, so the process where we're doing Ivy Bridge, that'll stay full. We see the demand signals continue to be strong and we're going through the inventory replenishment to get the freshest stuff into inventory. We have seen loadings come down
componenttext: At 22 nanometers, so the process where we're doing Ivy Bridge, that'll stay full. We see the demand signals continue to be strong and we're going through the inventory replenishment to get the freshest stuff into inventory. We have seen loadings come down some in 32 nanometer, not to the point that we're taking underload charges but to the point that we can start to take a little bit of that capacity off-line. And as I said to John's question, if I have to brand to predict, I think we'll find more of those opportunities over the course of the back half of this year.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012

componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Craig Ellis, Caris & Company.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Paul, just back on the Ultrabook topic. As you look into the back half of the year, how do you see the Ultrabook mix shaking out as a percent of notebooks? I think in the past, you've referenced a 40% of consumer notebooks by the end of this year. Is that
componenttext: Paul, just back on the Ultrabook topic. As you look into the back half of the year, how do you see the Ultrabook mix shaking out as a percent of notebooks? I think in the past, you've referenced a 40% of consumer notebooks by the end of this year. Is that still a reasonable number or how are you looking at that?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. We really haven't changed our view on that. A couple of things give us confidence there. One is the first half shipments on Ultrabooks were essentially right on our expectation set over 6 months ago. And the design pipeline for what we see in
componenttext: Yes, it is. We really haven't changed our view on that. A couple of things give us confidence there. One is the first half shipments on Ultrabooks were essentially right on our expectation set over 6 months ago. And the design pipeline for what we see in the second half and the price points that we see, we think, will get us there. In a softer selling season, I think these machines become even more attractive. And so they may -- I'm fairly confident we'll hit our volume goals with this in terms of the percent mix for the consumer notebooks.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And then switching gears, Stacy, you had mentioned in earlier commentary you'd come back to the NAND business side. I don't think I heard you do that, so I just thought I'd give you an opportunity to make any comment that you might have.
componenttext: Great. And then switching gears, Stacy, you had mentioned in earlier commentary you'd come back to the NAND business side. I don't think I heard you do that, so I just thought I'd give you an opportunity to make any comment that you might have.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was assuming someone was going to ask me the question. Yes, I -- we saw NAND soft in Q2. You saw on our commentary and as Paul alluded to. I don't think it's just us. I think you're seeing that from other companies. It's led to us being a little lower i
componenttext: I was assuming someone was going to ask me the question. Yes, I -- we saw NAND soft in Q2. You saw on our commentary and as Paul alluded to. I don't think it's just us. I think you're seeing that from other companies. It's led to us being a little lower in revenue. I think that continues as part of the lowering of expectations into the back half. There's a chunk of that that's NAND-related. I want to contrast it, though, it's really different compared to the last downturn we went through, which I think was about 4 years ago. You really see the impact of the strategy that we've been pursuing in that business. The fact that we now have process technology leadership and we've transitioned all of our shipments to higher-margin segments of the NAND market like SSDs and compute-NAND. So that even though while it's impacting us at the top line, it's a business that still is generating positive profit and it's still generating positive cash flow. I was a fairly new CFO when the last big downturn hit NAND and it was quite different because we didn't have that cost leadership and we were shipping into the commodity segments of the business. So I think it's a real testament to what they have accomplished in the business, but it's definitely soft.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Intel Q3 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mark Henninger. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Intel Q3 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mark Henninger. Please go ahead.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patrick, and welcome, everyone to Intel's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. By now, you should have received a copy of our earnings release and the CFO commentary that goes along with it. If you've not received both documents, they'r
componenttext:
Thank you, Patrick, and welcome, everyone to Intel's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. By now, you should have received a copy of our earnings release and the CFO commentary that goes along with it. If you've not received both documents, they're currently available on our investor website, www.intc.com. I'm joined today by Paul Otellini, our President and CEO; and Stacy Smith, our Chief Financial Officer.
In a moment, we'll hear brief remarks from both of them followed by the Q&A.
Before we begin, let me remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements based on the environment as we currently see it and, as such, does include risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our press release for more information on the specific risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially. Also if during this call we use any non-GAAP financial measures or references, we'll post the appropriate GAAP financial reconciliations to our website, intc.com. With that, let me hand it over to Paul.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter results came in slightly above our revised guidance, as PC related billings improved in September over the July and August levels. We believe that Q3 PC sales grew approximately 1/2 of the seas
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter results came in slightly above our revised guidance, as PC related billings improved in September over the July and August levels. We believe that Q3 PC sales grew approximately 1/2 of the seasonal norm and reflected flat enterprise sales. The billings upside we saw late in the quarter reflected our customers beginning their system production in advance of the Windows 8 launch later this month. As we look into to Q4, we believe that the overall PC business will grow at about half of what we would expect from normal seasonality. Our revenue forecast growth is below these levels as our customers are taking a cautious inventory approach in the face of market uncertainty and the timing of the Windows 8 launch. Our forecast assumes that incremental decrease in inventory at our customers going into year-end.
Our Data Center business saw the corporate servers segment softening over the course of the quarter, with the Cloud segment growing 50% over last year and storage revenue growing 27% to a new record. During the last month, I've met with all of our major customers, although the market remains tough, I'd been encouraged to see a renewed appetite for innovation across the entire ecosystem. Our customers are designing entirely new categories of PCs that will take advantage of our newest microprocessors, combined with Microsoft's new touch-enabled Windows 8 operating system to bring dozens of beautiful new tablet, convertible and Ultrabook designs to the market.
In the coming months, consumers will see tremendous form factor and industrial design innovation. There will be more than 140 core-based Ultrabooks, more than 40 of which will have touch. This will include more than a dozen convertibles that the combine the productivity of the laptop with the convenience of the tablet. Many of the Ultrabook SKUs will hit the mainstream $699 price but with some SKUs well below even that number. Q4 will see more than 20 Atom-based tablets from 6 or more OEMs using Clover Trail. Clover Trail is a brand-new SoC that will enable tablets to send 8.5 millimeters and as light as 1.5 pounds. With 3 weeks of Connected Standby battery life and all of the compatibility that Windows users and Intel customers have come to expect, I'm excited about these products and the capabilities they bring to the consumers and the enterprise.
Last month at IDF, we shared details of our next-generation core processor code-named Haswell. We originally targeted at 15 watts, we've made significant advancements significant advancements in micro architecture and process technology that will allow us to move Haswell down into the 10-watt envelope, clustering even more integration in form factor, as well as new usage models by computing and voice-recognition. We continue to make progress in handhelds, with Motorola's launch of the Razor I, the world's only 2 gigahertz smartphone that delivers better battery life than similar competing devices. In general, I see the computing market in a period of transition but also a period of breakthrough innovation and creativity. Intel has a history of navigating the industry's transitions and emerging better and stronger. With the hardware and software roadmap that spans the smallest portable devices to the most powerful Data Center servers and world-leading silicon process technology, we're excited about the future and confident in our strategy and prospects in all the markets we serve. With that, let me turn the call over to Stacy.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Third quarter revenue came in at $13.5 billion, flat from the second quarter and slightly better than our revised expectations. For the fourth quarter of 2012, we are forecasting the midpoint of the revenue range at $13.6 billion, up 1% from
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Third quarter revenue came in at $13.5 billion, flat from the second quarter and slightly better than our revised expectations. For the fourth quarter of 2012, we are forecasting the midpoint of the revenue range at $13.6 billion, up 1% from the third quarter. This slight increase in revenue in the fourth quarter reflects the caution that we are seeing in the order patterns of our customers as a result of concerns about the global environment, ongoing customer consumer softness in mature markets and a slowing enterprise market segment. As a result of weaker than expected demand environment, we are taking several actions. We significantly cut factory loading at the end of the quarter, and we're maintaining low factory utilization rates throughout the fourth quarter. We expect these factory adjustment to be helping done our total inventory levels by approximately $0.5 billion. Additionally, we are redirecting equipment and space to 40-nanometer from older generation technologies. The result of this is a $1.2 billion decrease from our July forecast for capital spending with the midpoint of our capital spending forecast for the year, now at $11.3 billion.
Moving to gross margin, third quarter gross margin of 63% was slightly better than the midpoint of our revised guidance and flat to the second quarter. We are forecasting the midpoint of our fourth quarter gross margin range to be 57%, down 6 points from the third quarter. 2/3 of the gross margin decline is the result of the excess capacity charges. In addition, we expect an increase in inventory reserves as we start production on our next-generation microarchitecture product code-named Haswell, which we expect to qualify for sale in the first quarter of 2013. Taking a look at the balance sheet, total cash investments ended the quarter at $10.5 billion, down approximately $3 billion to the second quarter.
We generated over $5 billion in cash from operations, paid approximately $1 billion in dividends, repurchased nearly $3 billion in capital assets and had roughly $1 billion of stock repurchases. In addition, we closed our $3 billion strategic equity investment in ASML. As a result of lower than expected sales in the third quarter, inventory grew by approximately $400 million. More of all -- more than all of the increase in inventories came from the Ivy Bridge product ramp, with an offset as we reduced inventory levels of older generation products.
We are taking aggressive tactical actions to reduce inventory levels and redirect space and equipment of 14-nanometer but we're also seeing some important positive trends in the market. In the client space, we are seeing innovative products coming to the market with Intel Inside, ranging from Ultrabooks to smartphones to tablets. In the Data Center, we expect to continue to benefit from the buildout of the cloud and a substantial performance cost and power benefit that our enterprise customers get from our leadership products. Underlying all of this, our manufacturing advantage is extending in the rest of the industry as we start the ramp of Haswell, our new microarchitecture 22-nanometer and began to build out our 40-nanometer factory effort. The combination of the technical actions we are taking coupled with new products and design wins across all segments and our manufacturing leadership will all benefit our business over the coming quarters. With that, let me turn it back over to Mark.

componenttext: Last I checked, I was still at BMO. First question is -- Stacy, just on this product cost cadence given that you're moderating the 40-nanometer a little bit. Typically, if I remember correctly, for 2 quarter cadence, how does that play out this time around?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not seeing anything that would cause it to be off of historical patterns. So if you look at what's happened in odd number years when we start the new process technology, you'll see an increase in start up costs that hits pretty significantly in Q1, go
componenttext: I'm not seeing anything that would cause it to be off of historical patterns. So if you look at what's happened in odd number years when we start the new process technology, you'll see an increase in start up costs that hits pretty significantly in Q1, goes up some more in Q2 and that will start to come down from there. So I'm not thinking of anything that would cause that to be different from historical patterns.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up is on the CapEx, Stacy, does that change from what you've given us during the 2012 Analyst Day for 2013?
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up is on the CapEx, Stacy, does that change from what you've given us during the 2012 Analyst Day for 2013?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're not putting out a forecast yet for 2013. '13 CapEx -- we're reducing '12 capital pretty significantly. 2013 will be a function of the unit growth that we see in '13 and our expectations for '14. And right now, we want to fight through our Q4 wh
componenttext: Yes. We're not putting out a forecast yet for 2013. '13 CapEx -- we're reducing '12 capital pretty significantly. 2013 will be a function of the unit growth that we see in '13 and our expectations for '14. And right now, we want to fight through our Q4 where we don't have a lot of visibility before we lock into our 2013 number.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Doug Freedman from RBC capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Doug Freedman from RBC capital.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Stacy, you gave a number at the Analyst Day regarding full year 2013 gross margin. Do you want to take -- can you give us some idea of what range you're looking at now that you are taking the actions you're presently communicating today?
componenttext: Stacy, you gave a number at the Analyst Day regarding full year 2013 gross margin. Do you want to take -- can you give us some idea of what range you're looking at now that you are taking the actions you're presently communicating today?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll -- we will provide a forecast for 2013 when we get to January. So again, similar to the prior question, yes, I think it's premature to provide a forecast at this point across revenue, gross margin or CapEx for '13. We need to fight through Q4 fi
componenttext: Yes. I'll -- we will provide a forecast for 2013 when we get to January. So again, similar to the prior question, yes, I think it's premature to provide a forecast at this point across revenue, gross margin or CapEx for '13. We need to fight through Q4 first. There's a couple of things that I think you can model for '13 though that are helpful. We'll just talk about the start up costs. We're starting up 14-nanometer. So historically, that's worth 2 to 3 points of gross margin. In terms of the excess capacity charges that we're taking, we're taking a lot in Q4. I think you'll see that significantly better in Q1 and then by the time we get to Q2, I don't expect really any excess capacity charges. So you'll see that play out. And just to size those 2 things, in Q1, I think the excess capacity charges in the start up costs are kind of roughly similar orders of magnitude. So those 2 things should offset. Beyond that, I'll wait until we get to January because there's just many moving parts for 2013.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: As my follow-up on the revenue side, we did see some movement this quarter, probably not completely expected PC Client, but little bit better than maybe you might have expected when you preannounced. But Data Center however though, is seeing some ASP move
componenttext: As my follow-up on the revenue side, we did see some movement this quarter, probably not completely expected PC Client, but little bit better than maybe you might have expected when you preannounced. But Data Center however though, is seeing some ASP movement that cost that revenue to be shot soft. Can you communicate to us what your outlook is as far as the revenue mix for next quarter and maybe what that might do to our gross margin number?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just -- come back to Q3 for second and I'll answer your question on Q4. What we saw really specifically in the client side of it -- it played out roughly as we thought when we did the preannouncement. And if you step back from that, what we saw wa
componenttext: Yes. So just -- come back to Q3 for second and I'll answer your question on Q4. What we saw really specifically in the client side of it -- it played out roughly as we thought when we did the preannouncement. And if you step back from that, what we saw was some growth in consumption but our customers continuing to manage inventories very lean and in fact, we saw across the worldwide PC supply chain, we actually saw a reduction in overall inventory levels in Q3 and normally in Q3, you see an increase. So we can kind of see a sense of how we're managing things. In the Data Center, what we saw was strong growth in the Internet IP Data Centers, the cloud. It was up actually 50% from a year ago. It was offset but we started to see some weakness on the enterprise side, and that's where you're seeing a lower ASP just because of the difference in ASP between those 2 segments. As we go into Q4 in terms of the overall mix of our business, when I look at the gross -- when I -- I'll direct you to the gross margin Recon. There's an issue there with excess capacity charges direct you we have some builds on Haswell, really ASP has not impact in gross margin. And so you can take from that, that we expected to continue to be kind of similar mix and are roughly benign ASP environment.
