componenttext: Paul, how do you assess how much of what's going on in the PC market right now is macro timing of Windows 8 versus kind of a more structural barriers that tablets and smartphones are plain and simple eating into the PC 10? How do you think about those dynamics?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think a bit of each. It might be reminiscent to quantify it, John. Clearly, we saw a softening in the Consumer segment. We talked about that when we get the preannouncement about a month ago, and the surprise there was that China, which has been very st
componenttext: I think a bit of each. It might be reminiscent to quantify it, John. Clearly, we saw a softening in the Consumer segment. We talked about that when we get the preannouncement about a month ago, and the surprise there was that China, which has been very strong, current weak upon us on top of a continuing weakness in mature markets of the U.S. and Western Europe. However, having said that, we did believe that when the numbers are all that the PC consumption did grow in Q3 at about 1/2 the normal seasonal rate and will also grow in Q4 at about 1/2 the normal seasonal rate. How much of that half-ing is macroeconomic versus the timing of the Windows 8 build and the share of wallet wore for tablets versus PCs? It's TBD. And we'll know a lot more about that 90 days from now after the Windows 8 launch, after we see Intel-based tablets start shipping, when people start playing with the operating system have all the touch-based Ultrabooks out there. We'll know a lot more. So we'll try to quantify that a bit more for you in 90 days. But right now, it's a bit of each.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then guys, as my follow-up, Stacy, I appreciate the fact that it's too early to talk about next year CapEx. But under utilization in Q4 is clearly helping you lower this year's CapEx a bit. And back in '09, off of about 1/2 the CapEx base, I think the
componenttext: And then guys, as my follow-up, Stacy, I appreciate the fact that it's too early to talk about next year CapEx. But under utilization in Q4 is clearly helping you lower this year's CapEx a bit. And back in '09, off of about 1/2 the CapEx base, I think the underutilization is around the credit crisis saved you about $1.5 billion in capital spending. Is this going to hold where as we go into '13, the lack -- the underutilization that allow you to save on CapEx and if you're twice the base then, can we think about a $3 billion number in total?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, again, it's too -- I'm not going to get into that level of granularity. You can see 2012 capital spending is down $1.2 billion from what we thought a quarter ago, but we have some indications that we were trending down a little bit. So that's a big ch
componenttext: No, again, it's too -- I'm not going to get into that level of granularity. You can see 2012 capital spending is down $1.2 billion from what we thought a quarter ago, but we have some indications that we were trending down a little bit. So that's a big chunk, and we'll talk about '13 when we get to January.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Wong from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Wong from Wells Fargo.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: You commented on Clover Trail tablets. Are you seeing any Ivy Bridge tablet designs in addition to the Microsoft service? And can you give us some idea of how many tablets maker you're currently making for Haswell tablet in the future?
componenttext: You commented on Clover Trail tablets. Are you seeing any Ivy Bridge tablet designs in addition to the Microsoft service? And can you give us some idea of how many tablets maker you're currently making for Haswell tablet in the future?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Oh boy. I can help you on the former, not the latter. On Ivy Bridge, there's I'd say handful, 5 to 8 something like that, that I've seen on the top of my head and for Haswell, it's too soon to tell. I mean, we have -- when you start seeing an Ultrabook wi
componenttext: Oh boy. I can help you on the former, not the latter. On Ivy Bridge, there's I'd say handful, 5 to 8 something like that, that I've seen on the top of my head and for Haswell, it's too soon to tell. I mean, we have -- when you start seeing an Ultrabook with a detachable touchscreen, is it a tablet? And it's based on Haswell. Is it a tablet? Is it an Ultrabook or is it the convertible? I don't know. What for these things as we go along. What I can tell you is that the level of innovation there is really unbounded, I haven't seen this for a long time. I think in terms of the near-term some season, unbounded if there are some Ivy Bridge ones, they tend to be skewed more towards the enterprise where our customers believe that their customers, the CIOs of the world want a high-performance tablet that is compatible, that is secure that runs all their enterprise software. So I think that's where you'll see those migrate versus the Clover trail stuff, which was going to be a bit more consumer centric.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And you said you expected to qualify Haswell in the fourth quarter. Will Haswell be appearing in systems in the fourth quarter or should we look for that a bit later in the year? But.
componenttext: Great. And you said you expected to qualify Haswell in the fourth quarter. Will Haswell be appearing in systems in the fourth quarter or should we look for that a bit later in the year? But.

componenttextpreview: First half.
componenttext: First half.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Christopher Danely from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Danely from JPMorgan.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: So Paul, can you just give us maybe just your take on what you think it's going to take to pull the PC industry out of this funk? And do you think that with the advent of tablets cannibalizing notebooks that we're never going to see, the growth in PCs we
componenttext: So Paul, can you just give us maybe just your take on what you think it's going to take to pull the PC industry out of this funk? And do you think that with the advent of tablets cannibalizing notebooks that we're never going to see, the growth in PCs we used, is it going to be something lower than what we've been used to?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Again, since we don't know how much of the flatness that we're seeing this year in PCs is a function of which of those variables that we talked about earlier, it's pretty hard to say that in good economic cycles that we wouldn't return to normal growth. B
componenttext: Again, since we don't know how much of the flatness that we're seeing this year in PCs is a function of which of those variables that we talked about earlier, it's pretty hard to say that in good economic cycles that we wouldn't return to normal growth. But what I get back to as I look at it out here, I don't think -- and I said this to you guys before, I don't think that the tablet, as we've seen it evolve over the last several years is the end state of computing. The innovation is going to start pouring in now that you have widely available SKUs on a widely distributed operating system that's now -- that will come from multiple vendors that can unleash their creativity. What I can't predict is what form factor is going in here. But I do think that some of these things that have sort of the best of both worlds, the performance and the capability of a laptop and the form factor and convenience of a tablet, are likely to be the things that are -- are the most high-volume runners. But we honestly won't know for 12 months.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up question for Stacy. Just a clarification on the Q1 gross margin, Stacy. So you've given us what the utilization rates underutilization cost look like. If you look at the typical seasonality for Q1, you guys are probably down like $1 billio
componenttext: And a follow-up question for Stacy. Just a clarification on the Q1 gross margin, Stacy. So you've given us what the utilization rates underutilization cost look like. If you look at the typical seasonality for Q1, you guys are probably down like $1 billion or something like that. So if sales were down $1 billion and depreciation is up a little bit and start up costs are up, can the margins be flat with current utilization rates? And what would inventory look like?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: You're trying to back me into a corner. I'm not -- I would maybe make a couple of comments so -- to your thesis. One is based on what we're seeing in the back half of this year, I'm less convinced that normal seasonality is a great guide. What we're seein
componenttext: You're trying to back me into a corner. I'm not -- I would maybe make a couple of comments so -- to your thesis. One is based on what we're seeing in the back half of this year, I'm less convinced that normal seasonality is a great guide. What we're seeing is the customers managing things very cautiously. Depending on how the sales go, I can get multiple different outcomes for Q1 and we'll get there in the quarter. In terms of inventory levels, we're too high today because the unit volume that we expected in September didn't materialize. We're a little -- we're under in what we thought in Q4. That's one of the reasons we're bringing the utilization down. We're bringing inventory levels down significantly in Q4 back into a healthy range and our intent would be to keep them in that range.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from CJ Muse from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from CJ Muse from Barclays.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess this is a follow-up on inventory side. Can you discuss what you're seeing downstream particularly in China? And then also as part of the my math suggests existing December roughly 75 days. Is that kind of the new normal we should think about for y
componenttext: I guess this is a follow-up on inventory side. Can you discuss what you're seeing downstream particularly in China? And then also as part of the my math suggests existing December roughly 75 days. Is that kind of the new normal we should think about for you guys in the low were PC growth rate environment or do you think that, that you need to be something more?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me try the China one, CJ and...
componenttext: Let me try the China one, CJ and...

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll do the inventory.
componenttext: I'll do the inventory.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was just in China 1.5 weeks ago, so I got a fairly current view. I see the same situation. I mean, China as a manufacturing center is reflecting the comments that we have in our commentary, which is that the OEMs are being very cautious with their inven
componenttext: I was just in China 1.5 weeks ago, so I got a fairly current view. I see the same situation. I mean, China as a manufacturing center is reflecting the comments that we have in our commentary, which is that the OEMs are being very cautious with their inventory commitment at this point in time for all the reasons we've discussed. And it's as lean as we've seen it in normal times without the shortage of let's say, the hard drives of last year. In terms of the channel inventory, there really isn't very much. I went into Tier 3 cities. You don't see things stocked up or stacked up on pallets and stuff. People are generally -- I think most of our customers worldwide spent a lot of Q3 thinning out their Windows 7 inventory, so they wouldn't have an overhang at the launch. And that accounts for a lot of this inventory shift of our buildings versus the consumption that we've been talking about. And now with the launch of Windows 8 coming in a week or so, you'll see a new round of build and hopefully consumption.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then in terms of the inventory targets, yes, the number you threw out is yes, in the 70s is where we're planning to get to in Q4. Just to put that in perspective, maybe to your comments on what we're doing. One is we're taking down utilization in
componenttext: Yes, and then in terms of the inventory targets, yes, the number you threw out is yes, in the 70s is where we're planning to get to in Q4. Just to put that in perspective, maybe to your comments on what we're doing. One is we're taking down utilization in the factories down to sub 50% again to take inventory out and create the opportunity to move both space and equipment and redirect that to 14 nanometer. So it's pretty significant series of actions. And as well I point to the inventory that we have in place in terms of units more than I want to hold, it's on the order of 70% Ivy Bridge. So it's our freshest stuff. So we're not worried not worried about the salability of inventory but I do want to bring the aggregate inventory levels down. It's just healthier to have less.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Cassidy from Stifel Nicholas.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Cassidy from Stifel Nicholas.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Maybe along those lines of the utilization or underutilization, in last year's investor meeting, Andy Bryant had presented -- his presentation was around the risk of too much capital spending and that Intel had one more fab building than needed. What woul
componenttext: Maybe along those lines of the utilization or underutilization, in last year's investor meeting, Andy Bryant had presented -- his presentation was around the risk of too much capital spending and that Intel had one more fab building than needed. What would we do? Is that part of our plan? Are you mothballed one building?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's more down the line of my presentation that I showed you we're constantly trying to match our capacity that's in place to the demand. We were putting capacity for a bigger second half than we got. We're going to now make adjustments so that we
componenttext: I'd say it's more down the line of my presentation that I showed you we're constantly trying to match our capacity that's in place to the demand. We were putting capacity for a bigger second half than we got. We're going to now make adjustments so that we can move capacity to 14 nanometer and bring our inventory levels down. It doesn't change the fact that our planning model are always looking to make sure we have the ability in terms of what we call white space so some unallocated factory space as well as equipment to respond to upsize we got. It's -- the risk of being caught short much more than because of being long because as you can see, when we come along, we can take action within a get better like if you're sure, can take you 2 years to get caught back up.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Their use of equipment, can you give me an idea what percent that this could be used from 22 nanometer to 14?
componenttext: Okay. Their use of equipment, can you give me an idea what percent that this could be used from 22 nanometer to 14?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's not different than our historical patterns. So you can think of it in the range of 80% to 90% of equipment that we buy, 22 nanometer is usable at the 14-nanometer node. It's -- and that's not by accident. It's one of things that technology spent
componenttext: Yes, it's not different than our historical patterns. So you can think of it in the range of 80% to 90% of equipment that we buy, 22 nanometer is usable at the 14-nanometer node. It's -- and that's not by accident. It's one of things that technology spent a lot of time to make sure we have these forward reuse paths because it gives us great flexibility to respond to things like we're seeing today.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Daniel Berenbaum from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Daniel Berenbaum from MKM Partners.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: When you talk about clearing inventory, this pricing coming to play in any fashion on the PC side -- a little side their datacenter side but their inventory on either the consumer side or the enterprise side, is that helping? And then follow-up also a lit
componenttext: When you talk about clearing inventory, this pricing coming to play in any fashion on the PC side -- a little side their datacenter side but their inventory on either the consumer side or the enterprise side, is that helping? And then follow-up also a little bit on an earlier question, is there anything else that Intel can be doing to spur demand? Obviously, see Microsoft take matters into their own hands with some of the designs that they're trying to sell. Is pricing helping you spur demand or is there something else that you can do?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Short answer to your question is no on pricing. The pricing is -- we do forward pricing with our customers. So it's priced I think aggressively to move into the mainstream price points in terms of the stuff I talked about. If you look at our PC group numb
componenttext: Short answer to your question is no on pricing. The pricing is -- we do forward pricing with our customers. So it's priced I think aggressively to move into the mainstream price points in terms of the stuff I talked about. If you look at our PC group numbers quarter-over-quarter, the ASP was about flat year-over-year. It was down a bit. Mobile was down a bit. What that reflects was really us going after some incremental share at the bottom of the market. So then we changed pricing but it changed the mix. And we thought it was time we could do some of that and we did it opportunistically. That's more the driver on that side. In terms of demand stimulation, a lot of what we're doing is really to make sure that the feature set of this season's Ultrabooks are really consistent with where the market is. That's why we're so focused on working on our customers and the ecosystems, for example, bringing the touch SKUs in. Six to 8 months ago, that we did not have the line of sight to 40 out of 140 SKUs of Ultrabooks being touched-enabled, that was probably 5 or 10. We're up to 40 now. It can actually get bigger as we go into 2013. So we can with the vendors in the glass manufacturers to bring the cost of such as an increment down has been one of the key things we think we can do to drive demand.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good. And related to pricing, you've obviously, got a wounded competitor out there now. Are you seeing that competitor get aggressive on pricing especially in this environment? Your competitor talked about big inventory write-down in this negative preanno
componenttext: Good. And related to pricing, you've obviously, got a wounded competitor out there now. Are you seeing that competitor get aggressive on pricing especially in this environment? Your competitor talked about big inventory write-down in this negative preannouncement. Are you seeing lower pricing there and is that in any way impacting to you?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think you have to ask them their strategy for pricing. As Paul said, we -- last quarter and this quarter, we believe we've won some share at the lower end of the market. That's our strategy here. And so you got to ask them the question there on their pr
componenttext: I think you have to ask them their strategy for pricing. As Paul said, we -- last quarter and this quarter, we believe we've won some share at the lower end of the market. That's our strategy here. And so you got to ask them the question there on their pricing strategy.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim Covello from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim Covello from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Guys, a kind of question stay on the margins. In the context of this cyclical history, what we're seeing here is not to unique from the standpoint of the margins usually declined pretty significantly on the other side of the big CapEx cycles. I think the
componenttext: Guys, a kind of question stay on the margins. In the context of this cyclical history, what we're seeing here is not to unique from the standpoint of the margins usually declined pretty significantly on the other side of the big CapEx cycles. I think the average margin decline is 700 basis points, the peak is 1,300 basis points. You're down about 1,000 basis points now from that the gross margins. So pretty normal. Is there anything you see in that context that would cause margin declined to be worse than some of the most more dramatic declines you've seen historically?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that when you go back and look across the long-range of history when we've seen a situation where the industry had a head-on capacity, the time that it took to get things realigned typically it was much longer than 2 quarters. I think we've
componenttext: Well, I think that when you go back and look across the long-range of history when we've seen a situation where the industry had a head-on capacity, the time that it took to get things realigned typically it was much longer than 2 quarters. I think we've done a lot to improve that the responsiveness. I think that has been helpful. And we saw that in 2009. But if you go back before that as opposed to a couple of quarters, you are sometimes up about a couple of years to get some capacity back in line. I think that's different. And the only thing I'd point to that's different is while the decline is significant and we're taking some excess capacity charges, if you compared 2000 -- what we're going through now in 2009, and 2009, we were in the mid- to high 40s, now we are in the mid- to high 50s and I think that really points to the structural improvements we've made in our business in terms of cost and mix in the competitiveness of our products. So while it may seem this into you, it actually I think is faster and we're still maintaining a higher gross margin.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Helpful. For my follow-up question is kind of specific to the Data Center Group. Some of the ARM-based server players are arguing that they can now address a significant part of the workload from same the same Google's and Amazon and Facebook's data cente
componenttext: Helpful. For my follow-up question is kind of specific to the Data Center Group. Some of the ARM-based server players are arguing that they can now address a significant part of the workload from same the same Google's and Amazon and Facebook's data centers. Is that some competitive dynamic that you're seeing in that area or do you think that ARM is still isn't competitive in that realm?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, they need to add feature sets like feature sets like 64-bit NPCC and RAS features to be particularly those environments to be considered. So that may be a roadmap planning opportunity but they're pushing with the products that are being ship
componenttext: Well, I mean, they need to add feature sets like feature sets like 64-bit NPCC and RAS features to be particularly those environments to be considered. So that may be a roadmap planning opportunity but they're pushing with the products that are being shipped today simply don't have those feature sets. You can look at some the workload things like Hadoop, Jim, that would be conducive to let me say an array of microservers. And those can easily be run on Atom. We've got our second generation of the Atom microserver chips out now, with the first one -- the first one on 32 nanometers, we're now sampling the 22-nanometer one. And we decided that we're just going to push at them as hard as possible on this space and have it be a better offering for our customers than having to switch all their software and worry about all the reliability features.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from JoAnne Feeney from Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from JoAnne Feeney from Longbow Research.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was hoping you could elaborate a little bit more on what you're seeing -- what you saw last quarter and would you expect this quarter in terms of the mix of demand both across consumer geographically and then PC notebook, desktops. Just some more c
componenttext: Yes, I was hoping you could elaborate a little bit more on what you're seeing -- what you saw last quarter and would you expect this quarter in terms of the mix of demand both across consumer geographically and then PC notebook, desktops. Just some more color if you would on what kind of mix you're seeing out there and where you're expected it to go and what -- what you're relying on to get those inventories clear, say, by the beginning of 2013?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the last part. The inventory thing is straight-forward, it's a work in process expect to come down over this quarter are Ivy Bridge products, which is a my mainstream, high-end product that we have today. So as the market picks up, Windo
componenttext: Let me start with the last part. The inventory thing is straight-forward, it's a work in process expect to come down over this quarter are Ivy Bridge products, which is a my mainstream, high-end product that we have today. So as the market picks up, Windows 8 launches, Ultrabooks pickup and so forth, that just assumes that inventory. And as I said earlier, in my comments and Stacy's, our OEMs are running very lean right now. So any kind of demand book would cause us to be able to reduce that even more perhaps. But in terms of the mix, there's really not much more to add than reported in the previously the comments today, which is that the U.S. and Western Europe PC markets remain soft in terms of consumers. The change that we have seen and we talked about at the preannouncement was that the enterprise PC market has gone relatively flat now. And I think that's just a reflection of large corporations making hard decisions on CapEx versus people and where they want to put their investments. And now that seems to have spilled over from the client side of the enterprise to also the Data Center server part of the enterprise. And I think we'll see how that sorts out over the next quarter or so, as CEOs and CIOs make their next round of decisions. In terms of China, the slowdown there was -- it's principally a notebook business and the slowdown there was in consumer notebooks

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I'd just add, in DCG, we saw strengthen in cloud customers and over the course of the quarter, weakening cloud in the large enterprises purchases of server chips. So that -- the mix there was more to the cloud.
componenttext: And I'd just add, in DCG, we saw strengthen in cloud customers and over the course of the quarter, weakening cloud in the large enterprises purchases of server chips. So that -- the mix there was more to the cloud.

componenttext: Which has been strong in the first half.

componenttext: Sorry, on the ASPs?

componenttext: The PC ASPs were down 1% and the server ASPs were down 7% based on the mix kind of things that I've been talking about.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Patrick Wang with Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Patrick Wang with Evercore Partners.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: First question. I wanted to see if you can go back to China and Paul, maybe kind of recap some of the feedback you're hearing from those meetings you did have. Because it seems like the slowdown in China is really impacting global PC demand and what we th
componenttext: First question. I wanted to see if you can go back to China and Paul, maybe kind of recap some of the feedback you're hearing from those meetings you did have. Because it seems like the slowdown in China is really impacting global PC demand and what we think out there. So just curious what the latest you're hearing.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, there is -- what I don't know is how much of this is in China, is their own macroeconomic cycles going down. I mean, the GDP forecast for the year have come down for the next year have come down. There's also a reasonable amount of anxiety around th
componenttext: Well, there is -- what I don't know is how much of this is in China, is their own macroeconomic cycles going down. I mean, the GDP forecast for the year have come down for the next year have come down. There's also a reasonable amount of anxiety around the change in government. And that tends to that a little bit of their business into the system and what I don't know how much of that clarifies after they change because people -- it's not so much they don't know who's coming in, the issue is what are the policies in terms of stimulus and taxation and so forth. It would've been pretty generous to last year, so a year or 2 rather in terms of stimulating domestic consumption and the question is will those policies continue or not.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got you. That's hopeful. And I wanted to talk a little bit about Data Center. The trend that we're seeing in ASPs right now down 7% last quarter, I'm just kind of curious how you see that over the next couple of years here, because when we take a look at
componenttext: Got you. That's hopeful. And I wanted to talk a little bit about Data Center. The trend that we're seeing in ASPs right now down 7% last quarter, I'm just kind of curious how you see that over the next couple of years here, because when we take a look at your Cloud segment forecasting pretty robust growth there, you talked about 50% of growth last quarter. Has that continues to really outstrip growth from your more traditional server customers? I mean, what of the -- what kind of impact do you're bonded ASPs?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think the better comparison for the Data Center is that year-over-year, which is that ASP was up a bit, up 1%. But down a bit is really a big shift in the mix between what would be normal enterprise growth and of slowing in the enterprise growth. In gen
componenttext: I think the better comparison for the Data Center is that year-over-year, which is that ASP was up a bit, up 1%. But down a bit is really a big shift in the mix between what would be normal enterprise growth and of slowing in the enterprise growth. In general, for storage, for networking and I think for some aspect of the Internet Data Center, the mix is actually quite good. Sometimes two-way machines versus four-way machines but they tend to put a fairly high mix. And while the fastest-growing elements of the business is High-performance computing, which buyers buys the top-of-the-line of our SKUs. So as those product lines that flushed out more and more, I really don't see the mix shifting away from where it's been the first half of this year. I see the current mix being a bit of an anomaly as a result of the softness of corporate Data Center servers repurchases.

componenttext: And then Paul, a question for you. Notionally we would expect to see when we have an operating transition like we're seeing a spark to PC demand and yet we don't seem to be seeing that. What I wonder is if you could just give us your thoughts as to why you think this might happened?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I mean -- we know this hasn't happened yet. I'm very excited by this operating system as I said earlier, it brings touch into the mainstream for the first time and we know that the last couple of years, the tablets have changed the paradigm for people to
componenttext: I mean -- we know this hasn't happened yet. I'm very excited by this operating system as I said earlier, it brings touch into the mainstream for the first time and we know that the last couple of years, the tablets have changed the paradigm for people to use computers. They like touch, they like to take their photos, get larger with their fingers and everything else is good about that. So I think we haven't had a chance to really judge how the consumers will embrace this in mainstream PC space or not. I'm very optimistic as we've been playing with these things and we see the products being built and we take them out for testing to consumers that would now run tests on Windows 8, touch-enabled Ultrabooks in a number of the major cities around the world and across mobile demographics. The feedback is universally positive. So I think we're just too soon to tell. The darn thing that it hasn't even launched yet. And we'll know a lot more about this 90 days from now.

Two questions. First question for either Paul or Stacy. First you noted that inventories are I mean, and you expect that half the normal seasonal growth in PCs but you're failing down that number.
Is the -- if the set up is lean from an inventory perspective, why our customers choosing to take down inventories even further or is that just a cushion you're building into your forecast for the fourth quarter?

componenttext: I think it's just caution. We're seeing a very cautious environments, I mean, I think it's a combination of what we're seeing from a macro standpoint and a slowing enterprise and the operating system transition and a weak consumer market segment. I think all of that this just leading people to be cautious. Ultimately, I think leaner inventory levels are healthy but that's what we're seeing right now.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Intel Q3 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mark Henninger. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Intel Q3 2012 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mark Henninger. Please go ahead.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Patrick, and welcome, everyone to Intel's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. By now, you should have received a copy of our earnings release and the CFO commentary that goes along with it. If you've not received both documents, they'r
componenttext:
Thank you, Patrick, and welcome, everyone to Intel's Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. By now, you should have received a copy of our earnings release and the CFO commentary that goes along with it. If you've not received both documents, they're currently available on our investor website, intc.com. I'm joined today by Paul Otellini, our President and CEO; and Stacy Smith, our Chief Financial Officer. In a moment, we'll hear brief remarks from both of them followed by the Q&A.
Before we begin, let me remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements based on the environment as we currently see it and, as such, does include risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our press release for more information on the specific risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially. Also if during the call we use any non-GAAP financial measures or references, we'll post the appropriate reconciliations to our website, intc.com.
With that, let me hand it over to Paul.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter results came in slightly above our revised guidance, as PC-related billings improved in September over their July and August levels. We believe that Q3 PC sales grew approximately 1/2 of the se
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter results came in slightly above our revised guidance, as PC-related billings improved in September over their July and August levels. We believe that Q3 PC sales grew approximately 1/2 of the seasonal norm and reflected flat enterprise sales. The billings upside we saw late in the quarter reflected our customers beginning their system production in advance of the Windows 8 launch later this month. As we look into Q4, we believe that the overall PC business will grow at about 1/2 of what we would expect from normal seasonality. Our revenue forecast growth is below these levels as our customers are taking a cautious inventory approach in the face of market uncertainty and the timing of the Windows 8 launch. Our forecast assumes an incremental decrease in inventory at our customers going into year end.
Our Data Center business saw the corporate servers segment softening over the course of the quarter, with the cloud segment growing 50% over last year and storage revenue growing 27% to a new record.
During the last month, I've met with all of our major customers. And while the market remains tough, I've been encouraged to see a renewed appetite for innovation across the entire ecosystem. Our customers are designing entirely new categories of PCs that will take advantage of our newest microprocessors, combined with Microsoft's new touch-enabled Windows 8 operating system to bring dozens of beautiful new tablet, convertible and Ultrabook designs to the market.
In the coming months, consumers will see tremendous form factor and industrial design innovation. There will be more than 140 Core-based Ultrabooks, more than 40 of which will have touch. This will include more than a dozen convertibles that combine the productivity of the laptop with the convenience of a tablet. Many of the Ultrabook SKUs will hit the mainstream $699 price point, with some burst SKUs well below even that number. Q4 will see more than 20 Atom-based tablets from 6 or more leading OEMs using Clover Trail. Clover Trail is a brand-new SoC that will enable tablets as thin as 8.5 millimeters and as light as 1.5 pounds, with 3 weeks of Connected Standby battery life and all of the compatibility that Windows users and Intel customers have come to expect. I'm excited about these products and the capabilities they bring to consumers and the enterprise.
Last month at IDF, we shared details of our next-generation Core processor codenamed Haswell. Originally targeted at 15 watts, we've made significant advancements in microarchitecture and process technology that will allow us to move Haswell down into the 10-watt envelope, fostering even more innovation in form factor, as well as new usage models like gesture computing and voice recognition. We continue to make progress in handhelds, with Motorola's launch of the RAZR i, the world's only 2 gigahertz smartphone that delivers better battery life than similar competing devices. In general, I see the computing market in a period of transition, but also a period of breakthrough innovation and creativity. Intel has a history of navigating the industry's transitions and emerging better and stronger. With a hardware and software roadmap that spans the smallest portable devices, to the most powerful data center servers and world-leading silicon process technology, we're excited about the future and confident in our strategy and prospects in all the markets we serve.
With that, let me turn the call over to Stacy.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Third quarter revenue came in at $13.5 billion, flat from the second quarter and slightly better than our revised expectations. For the fourth quarter of 2012, we are forecasting the midpoint of the revenue range at $13.6 billion, up 1% from
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Third quarter revenue came in at $13.5 billion, flat from the second quarter and slightly better than our revised expectations. For the fourth quarter of 2012, we are forecasting the midpoint of the revenue range at $13.6 billion, up 1% from the third quarter. This slight increase in revenue in the fourth quarter reflects the caution we are seeing in the order patterns of our customers as a result of concerns about the global economic environment, ongoing consumer softness in mature markets and a slowing enterprise market segment. As a result of weaker than expected demand environment, we are taking several actions. We significantly cut factory loading at the end of the quarter and will maintaining low factory utilization rates throughout the fourth quarter. We expect these factory adjustment to help bring down our total inventory levels by approximately $0.5 billion. Additionally, we are redirecting equipment and space to 14-nanometer from older generation technologies. The result of this is a $1.2 billion decrease from our July forecast for capital spending, with the midpoint of our capital spending forecast for the year now at $11.3 billion.
Moving to gross margin, third quarter gross margin of 63% was slightly better than the midpoint of our revised guidance and flat to the second quarter. We are forecasting the midpoint of our fourth quarter gross margin range to be 57%, down 6 points from the third quarter. 2/3 of the gross margin decline is the result of the excess capacity charges. In addition, we expect an increase in inventory reserves as we start production on our next-generation microarchitecture product codenamed Haswell, which we expect to qualify for sale in the first quarter of 2013. Taking a look at the balance sheet, total cash investments ended the quarter at $10.5 billion, down approximately $3 billion to the second quarter.
We generated over $5 billion in cash from operations, paid approximately $1 billion in dividends, repurchased nearly $3 billion in capital assets and had roughly $1 billion of stock repurchases. In addition, we closed our $3 billion strategic equity investment in ASML. As a result of lower-than-expected sales in the third quarter, inventory grew by approximately $400 million. More of all -- more than all of the increase in inventories came from the Ivy Bridge product ramp, with an offset as we reduced inventory levels of older generation products.
We are taking aggressive tactical actions to reduce inventory levels and redirect space and equipment to 14-nanometer, but we're also seeing some important positive trends in the market. In the client space, we are seeing innovative products coming to the market with Intel Inside, ranging from Ultrabooks to smartphones to tablets. In the Data Center, we expect to continue to benefit from the buildout of the cloud and a substantial performance, cost and power benefit that our enterprise customers get from our leadership products. Underlying all of this, our manufacturing advantage is extending over the rest of the industry as we start the ramp of Haswell, our new microarchitecture on 22-nanometer, and begin to build out our 14-nanometer factory network. The combination of the tactical actions we are taking, coupled with new products and design wins across all segments, and our manufacturing leadership will all benefit our business over the coming quarters.
With that, let me turn it back over to Mark.

componenttext: Last I checked, I was still with BMO. First question is -- Stacy, just on the -- this product cost cadence given that you're moderating to 14-nanometer a little bit. Typically, if I remember correctly, it's a 2 quarter cadence. How does that play out this time around?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not seeing anything that would cause it to be off of historical patterns. So if you look at what's happened in odd number years when we start up a new process technology, you'll see an increase in start-up costs that hits pretty significantly in Q1, g
componenttext: I'm not seeing anything that would cause it to be off of historical patterns. So if you look at what's happened in odd number years when we start up a new process technology, you'll see an increase in start-up costs that hits pretty significantly in Q1, goes up some more in Q2 and then will start to come down from there. So I'm not seeing anything that would cause that to be different from historical patterns.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012

componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up is on the CapEx, Stacy. Does that change from what you had given us during the 2012 Analyst Day for 2013?

componenttextpreview: Yes. We're not putting out a forecast yet for 2013. '13 CapEx -- we're reducing '12 capital pretty significantly. 2013 will be a function of the unit growth that we see in '13 and our expectations for '14. Right now, we want to fight through a Q4 where we
componenttext: Yes. We're not putting out a forecast yet for 2013. '13 CapEx -- we're reducing '12 capital pretty significantly. 2013 will be a function of the unit growth that we see in '13 and our expectations for '14. Right now, we want to fight through a Q4 where we don't have a lot of visibility before we lock in on a 2013 number.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Doug Freedman from RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Doug Freedman from RBC Capital.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Stacy, you gave a number at the Analyst Day though regarding full year 2013 gross margin. Do you want to take -- can you give us some idea of what range you're looking at now that you are taking the actions you're presently communicating today?
componenttext: Stacy, you gave a number at the Analyst Day though regarding full year 2013 gross margin. Do you want to take -- can you give us some idea of what range you're looking at now that you are taking the actions you're presently communicating today?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll -- we will provide a forecast for 2013 when we get to January. So again, similar to the prior question, yes, I think it's premature to provide a forecast at this point across revenue or gross margin or CapEx for '13. We need to fight through Q4
componenttext: Yes. I'll -- we will provide a forecast for 2013 when we get to January. So again, similar to the prior question, yes, I think it's premature to provide a forecast at this point across revenue or gross margin or CapEx for '13. We need to fight through Q4 first. There's a couple of things that I think you can model for '13 though that are helpful. We just talked about the start-up costs. We're starting up 14-nanometer. So historically, that's worth 2 to 3 points of gross margin. In terms of the excess capacity charges that we're taking, we're taking a lot in Q4. I think we'll see that significantly better in Q1, and then by the time we get to Q2, I don't expect really any excess capacity charges. So you'll see that play out. And just to size those 2 things in Q1, I think the excess capacity charges and the start-up costs are kind of roughly similar orders of magnitude. So those 2 things should offset. Beyond that, I'll wait until we get to January because there's just many other moving parts for 2013.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: So as my follow-up, on the revenue side, we did see some movement this quarter. Probably not completely expected, PC Client a little bit better than maybe you might have expected when you preannounced. The Data Center, however though, is seeing some ASP m
componenttext: So as my follow-up, on the revenue side, we did see some movement this quarter. Probably not completely expected, PC Client a little bit better than maybe you might have expected when you preannounced. The Data Center, however though, is seeing some ASP movement that caused that revenue to be soft. Can you communicate to us what your outlook is as far as the revenue mix for next quarter and maybe what that might do to our gross margin number?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just to come back to Q3 for a second, then I'll answer your question on Q4. What we saw specifically in the client side -- it played out roughly as we thought when we did the pre-announcement. And if you step back from that, what we saw was some g
componenttext: Yes. So just to come back to Q3 for a second, then I'll answer your question on Q4. What we saw specifically in the client side -- it played out roughly as we thought when we did the pre-announcement. And if you step back from that, what we saw was some growth in consumption, but our customers continuing to manage inventories very lean. And in fact, we saw across the worldwide PC supply chain, we actually saw a reduction in overall inventory levels in Q3. And normally in Q3, you'd see an increase. So you can kind of get a sense of how lean they're managing things. In the Data Center, what we saw was strong growth in the Internet IP data centers, the cloud. It was up actually 50% from a year ago. It was offset when we started to see some weakness on the enterprise side, and that's where you're seeing the lower ASP, just because of the difference in ASP between those 2 segments. As we go into Q4, in terms of the overall mix of our business, when I look at the gross -- when I -- I'll direct you to the gross margin recon. There's an issue there with the excess capacity charges. We have some builds on Haswell, really ASP is not a impact in gross margin. And so you can take from that, that we expect it to continue to be kind of similar mix in a roughly benign ASP environment.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Pitzer from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Paul, how do you assess how much of what's going on in the PC market right now is macro, timing of Windows 8 versus kind of the more structural bearish view that tablets and smartphones are just plain and simple eating into the PC TAM? How do you think ab
componenttext: Paul, how do you assess how much of what's going on in the PC market right now is macro, timing of Windows 8 versus kind of the more structural bearish view that tablets and smartphones are just plain and simple eating into the PC TAM? How do you think about those dynamics?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's a bit of each, and I'd be reticent to quantify it, John. Clearly, we saw a softening in the Consumer segment. We talked about that when we did the pre-announcement about a month ago. And the surprise there was that China, which had been very
componenttext: I think it's a bit of each, and I'd be reticent to quantify it, John. Clearly, we saw a softening in the Consumer segment. We talked about that when we did the pre-announcement about a month ago. And the surprise there was that China, which had been very strong, turned weak on us on top of a continuing weakness in the mature markets of the U.S. and Western Europe. However, having said that, we do believe that when the numbers are all in, that PC consumption did grow in Q3 at about 1/2 the normal seasonal rate and will also grow in Q4 at about 1/2 the normal seasonal rate. How much of that half-ing is macroeconomic versus the timing of the Windows 8 build and the share of wallet war for tablets versus PCs is TBD. And we'll know a lot more about that 3 -- or 90 days from now after the Windows 8 launch, after we see Intel-based tablets start shipping, when people start playing with the operating system, have all the touch-based Ultrabooks out there, we'll know a lot more. So we'll try to quantify that a bit more for you in 90 days. But right now, it's a bit of each.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then guys, as my follow-up, Stacy, I appreciate the fact that it's too early to talk about next year CapEx. But underutilization in Q4 is clearly helping you kind of lower this year's CapEx a bit. And back in '09, off of about 1/2 the CapEx base, I th
componenttext: And then guys, as my follow-up, Stacy, I appreciate the fact that it's too early to talk about next year CapEx. But underutilization in Q4 is clearly helping you kind of lower this year's CapEx a bit. And back in '09, off of about 1/2 the CapEx base, I think the underutilization around the credit crisis saved you about $1.5 billion in capital spending. Is this going to hold where, as we go into '13, the lack of -- your underutilization will allow you to save on CapEx? And if you're twice the base then, can we think about a $3 billion number in total?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. Again, it's too -- I'm not going to get to that level of granularity. You can see that 2012 capital spending is down $1.2 billion from what we thought a quarter ago, although we had some indications that we were trending down a little bit. So that's a
componenttext: No. Again, it's too -- I'm not going to get to that level of granularity. You can see that 2012 capital spending is down $1.2 billion from what we thought a quarter ago, although we had some indications that we were trending down a little bit. So that's a big chunk, and we'll talk about '13 when we get to January.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Wong from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Wong from Wells Fargo.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: You commented on Clover Trail tablets. Are you seeing many Ivy Bridge tablet designs in addition to the Microsoft Surface? And can you give us some idea of how many tablet makers you're currently working with on Haswell tablets for the future?
componenttext: You commented on Clover Trail tablets. Are you seeing many Ivy Bridge tablet designs in addition to the Microsoft Surface? And can you give us some idea of how many tablet makers you're currently working with on Haswell tablets for the future?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Oh, boy. I can help you on the former, not the latter. On Ivy Bridge, there's, I'd say, a handful, 5 to 8 something like that, that I've seen, off the top of my head. And for Haswell, it's too soon to tell. I mean, we have -- when you start seeing an Ultr
componenttext: Oh, boy. I can help you on the former, not the latter. On Ivy Bridge, there's, I'd say, a handful, 5 to 8 something like that, that I've seen, off the top of my head. And for Haswell, it's too soon to tell. I mean, we have -- when you start seeing an Ultrabook with a detachable touchscreen, is it a tablet? And it's based on Haswell. Is it a tablet? Is it an Ultrabook? Or is it a convertible? Even I don't know. We'll have to invent some names for these things as we go along. What I can tell you is that the level of innovation there is really unbounded. I haven't seen this in a long time. But I think in terms of -- just looping near-term selling season, there are some Ivy Bridge ones. They tend to be skewed more towards the enterprise, where our customers believe that their customers, the CIOs of the world want a high-performance tablet that is compatible, that is secure, that runs all their enterprise software. So I think that's where you'll see those migrate versus, say, the Clover Trail stuff, which was going to be a bit more consumer-centric.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And you said you expected to qualify Haswell in the March quarter. Will Haswell be appearing in systems in the March quarter or should we look for that a bit later in the year?
componenttext: Great. And you said you expected to qualify Haswell in the March quarter. Will Haswell be appearing in systems in the March quarter or should we look for that a bit later in the year?
