headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was just in China 1.5 weeks ago, so I've got a fairly current view. I see the same situation. I mean, China as a manufacturing center is reflecting the comments that we had in our commentary, which is that the OEMs are being very cautious with their inv
componenttext: I was just in China 1.5 weeks ago, so I've got a fairly current view. I see the same situation. I mean, China as a manufacturing center is reflecting the comments that we had in our commentary, which is that the OEMs are being very cautious with their inventory commits at this point in time for all the reasons we've discussed. And it's as lean as we've seen it in normal times, even without the shortage of, let's say, the hard drives of last year. In terms of the channel inventory, there really isn't very much. I went into a Tier 3 city. You don't see things stocked up or stacked up on pallets and stuff. People are generally -- I think most of our customers worldwide spent a lot of Q3 thinning out their Windows 7 inventory, so they wouldn't have an overhang at the launch. And that accounts for a lot of this inventory shift of our billings versus the consumption that we've been talking about. And now with the launch of Windows 8 coming in a week or so, you'll see a new round of build and hopefully consumption.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then in terms of the inventory targets, yes, the number you threw out is yes, in the 70s is where we're planning to get to in Q4. Just to put that in perspective, maybe 2 other comments on what we're doing. One is, we're taking down utilization i
componenttext: Yes, and then in terms of the inventory targets, yes, the number you threw out is yes, in the 70s is where we're planning to get to in Q4. Just to put that in perspective, maybe 2 other comments on what we're doing. One is, we're taking down utilization in the factories down to sub-50%. Again, to take inventory out and to free up the opportunity to move both space and equipment and redirect that to 14-nanometer. So it's a pretty significant series of actions. And I also want to point to the inventory that we have in place. While it's in terms of units more than I want to hold, it's on the order of 70% Ivy Bridge. So it's our freshest stuff. So I'm not worried about the salability of the inventory, but I do want to bring the aggregate inventory levels down. It's just healthier for us to have less.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Cassidy from Stifel, Nicholas.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Cassidy from Stifel, Nicholas.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Maybe along those lines still of the utilization or underutilization. In last year's investor meeting, Andy Bryant had presented -- his presentation was around the risk of too much capital spending and that Intel had one more fab building than needed. Wha
componenttext: Maybe along those lines still of the utilization or underutilization. In last year's investor meeting, Andy Bryant had presented -- his presentation was around the risk of too much capital spending and that Intel had one more fab building than needed. What would we do? Is this part of that plan? Are you mothballing one building?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's more down the line of my presentation where I showed you when we -- that we're constantly trying to match our capacity that's in place to the demand. We were putting on capacity for a bigger second half than we got. We're going to now make ad
componenttext: I'd say it's more down the line of my presentation where I showed you when we -- that we're constantly trying to match our capacity that's in place to the demand. We were putting on capacity for a bigger second half than we got. We're going to now make adjustments so that we can move capacity to 14-nanometer and bring our inventory levels down. It doesn't change the fact that our planning model -- we're always looking to make sure we have the ability in terms of what we call white space, so some unallocated factory space, as well as some equipment to respond to upsides. It's -- the risk of being caught short and the cost of being caught short is much more than the cost of being long. Because as you can see when we get a little long, we can take actions and within a 6-month period we can get back aligned. If you're short, it can take you 2 years to get caught back up.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. I see. And with the reuse of equipment, can you give an idea of what percentage that is that can be reused from 22-nanometer to 14?
componenttext: Okay. I see. And with the reuse of equipment, can you give an idea of what percentage that is that can be reused from 22-nanometer to 14?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's not different than our historical patterns. So you can think of it in the range of 80% to 90% of the equipment that we buy at 22-nanometer is usable at the 14-nanometer node. It's -- and that's not by accident. It's one of things that technologi
componenttext: Yes. It's not different than our historical patterns. So you can think of it in the range of 80% to 90% of the equipment that we buy at 22-nanometer is usable at the 14-nanometer node. It's -- and that's not by accident. It's one of things that technologists spend a lot of time to make sure we have these forward reuse paths because it gives us great flexibility to respond to things like we're seeing today.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Daniel Berenbaum from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Daniel Berenbaum from MKM Partners.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: When you talk about clearing inventory, does pricing come into play in any fashion on the PC side? Could you talk about pricing a little bit on the data center side? But clearing inventory on either the consumer side or the enterprise side, is that helpin
componenttext: When you talk about clearing inventory, does pricing come into play in any fashion on the PC side? Could you talk about pricing a little bit on the data center side? But clearing inventory on either the consumer side or the enterprise side, is that helping? And then a follow-up also a little bit on an earlier question, is there anything else that Intel can be doing to spur demand? We've obviously seen sort of Microsoft take matters a bit into their own hands with some of the designs that they are trying to sell. Is pricing helping you spur demand or is there something else that you can do?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: The short answer to your question is no on pricing. The pricing is -- we do forward pricing with our customers. It's priced I think aggressively to move into the mainstream price points in terms of the stuff I talked about. If you look at our PC group num
componenttext: The short answer to your question is no on pricing. The pricing is -- we do forward pricing with our customers. It's priced I think aggressively to move into the mainstream price points in terms of the stuff I talked about. If you look at our PC group numbers quarter-over-quarter, the ASP was about flat year-over-year. It was down a bit. Mobile was down a bit. What that reflects was really us going after some incremental share at the bottom of the market. So it didn't really change pricing, but it changed the mix. And we thought it was time we could do some of that, and we did it opportunistically. That's more the driver on that side. In terms of demand stimulation, a lot of what we're doing is really to make sure that the feature set of this season's Ultrabooks are really consistent with where the market is. That's why we've been so focused on working with our customers and the ecosystem, just for example, bringing the touch SKUs in. 6 to 8 months ago, that we did not have line of sight to 40 out of 140 SKUs of Ultrabooks being touched-enabled. It was probably 5 or 10. We're up to 40 now. And that's just going to get bigger as we go into 2013. So working with the vendors and the glass manufacturers to bring the cost of touch as an increment down has been one of the key things we think we can do to drive demand.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good. And related to pricing, you've obviously got a wounded competitor out there now. Are you seeing that competitor get aggressive on pricing especially in this environment? Your competitor talked about a big inventory write-down in its negative pre-ann
componenttext: Good. And related to pricing, you've obviously got a wounded competitor out there now. Are you seeing that competitor get aggressive on pricing especially in this environment? Your competitor talked about a big inventory write-down in its negative pre-announcement. Are you seeing lower pricing there and is that in any way impacting you?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think you have to ask them their strategy for pricing. As Paul said, we -- last quarter and this quarter, we believe we've won some share at the lower end of the market. That's our strategy here. So you've got to ask them the question of their pricing s
componenttext: I think you have to ask them their strategy for pricing. As Paul said, we -- last quarter and this quarter, we believe we've won some share at the lower end of the market. That's our strategy here. So you've got to ask them the question of their pricing strategy.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jim Covello from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jim Covello from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Guys, a kind of question staying on the margins. In the context of cyclical history, what we're seeing here isn't too unique from the standpoint of, yes, the margins usually decline pretty significantly on the other side of the big CapEx cycles. I think t
componenttext: Guys, a kind of question staying on the margins. In the context of cyclical history, what we're seeing here isn't too unique from the standpoint of, yes, the margins usually decline pretty significantly on the other side of the big CapEx cycles. I think the average margin decline is 700 basis points. The peak is 1,300 basis points. You're down about 1,000 basis points now from the peak gross margins, so pretty normal. Is there anything you see in that context that would cause this margin decline to be worse than some of the more dramatic declines you've seen historically?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that when you go back and look across a long range of history when we've seen a situation where the industry got a hit on capacity, the time that it took to get things realigned typically was much longer than 2 quarters. I think we've done a
componenttext: Well, I think that when you go back and look across a long range of history when we've seen a situation where the industry got a hit on capacity, the time that it took to get things realigned typically was much longer than 2 quarters. I think we've done a lot to improve that responsiveness, and I think that has been helpful, and you saw that in 2009. But if you go back before that, as opposed to a couple of quarters, you were sometimes talking about a couple of years to get capacity back in line. I think that's different. And then the other thing I'd point to that's different is, while the decline is significant and we're taking some excess capacity charges, if you compare 2000 -- what we're going through now with 2009. In 2009, we were into the mid-to-high 40s, now we're in the mid-to-high 50s, and I think that really points to the structural improvements we've made in our business in terms of cost and mix and the competitiveness of our products. So while it may seem the same to you, it actually I think is faster, and we are still maintaining a higher gross margin.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Helpful. For my follow-up question is kind of specific to the Data Center Group. Some of the ARM-based server players are arguing that they can now address a significant part of the workload from the Googles and the Amazons and Facebooks data centers. Is
componenttext: Helpful. For my follow-up question is kind of specific to the Data Center Group. Some of the ARM-based server players are arguing that they can now address a significant part of the workload from the Googles and the Amazons and Facebooks data centers. Is that some competitive dynamic that you're seeing in that area or do you think that ARM is still isn't competitive in that realm?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, they need to add feature sets, like 64-bit and ECC and RAS features to be -- particularly in those environments to be considered. So that may be a roadmap planning opportunity that they're pushing, but the products that are being shipped tod
componenttext: Well, I mean, they need to add feature sets, like 64-bit and ECC and RAS features to be -- particularly in those environments to be considered. So that may be a roadmap planning opportunity that they're pushing, but the products that are being shipped today certainly don't have those feature sets. You can look at some the workloads, things like Hadoop, Jim, that would be conducive to, let me say, an array of microservers. And those can easily be run on Atom. We've got our second generation of the Atom microserver chips out now, with the first one on -- the first one's on 32 nanometers now, we're now sampling the 22-nanometer one. And we've decided that we're just going to push Atom as hard as possible in this space and have it be a better offering for our customers than having to switch all their software and worry about all the reliability features.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from JoAnne Feeney from Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from JoAnne Feeney from Longbow Research.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was hoping you could elaborate a little bit more on what you're seeing -- what you saw last quarter and what you expect this quarter in terms of the mix of demand both across consumer or enterprise geographically and then PC, notebook, desktops. Ju
componenttext: Yes, I was hoping you could elaborate a little bit more on what you're seeing -- what you saw last quarter and what you expect this quarter in terms of the mix of demand both across consumer or enterprise geographically and then PC, notebook, desktops. Just some more color, if you would, on what kind of mix you're seeing out there and where you expect it to go and what -- what you're relying on to get those inventories clear, say, by the beginning of 2013?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the last part. The inventory thing is straightforward. The work in process and finished goods that we're expecting to come down over this quarter are our Ivy Bridge products, which is the mainstream, high-end product we have today. So --
componenttext: Let me start with the last part. The inventory thing is straightforward. The work in process and finished goods that we're expecting to come down over this quarter are our Ivy Bridge products, which is the mainstream, high-end product we have today. So -- and as the market picks up, Windows 8 launches, Ultrabooks pickup and so forth, that just consumes that inventory. And as I said earlier, in my comments and Stacy's, our OEMs are running very lean right now. So any kind of demand blip would cause us to be able to reduce that even more perhaps. In terms of the mix, there's really not much more to add than we put in our prerelease and in the comments today, which is that, the U.S. and Western Europe PC markets remain soft in terms of consumers. The change that we have seen and we talked about at the pre-announcement, was that the enterprise PC market has gone relatively flat now. And I think that's just a reflection of large corporations making hard decisions on CapEx versus people and where they want to put their investments. And now that seems to have spilled over from the client side of the enterprise to also the data center server part of the enterprise. And I think we'll see how that sorts out over the next quarter or so as CEOs and CIOs make their next round of decisions. In terms of China, the slowdown there was -- it's principally a notebook business, and the slowdown there was in consumer notebooks.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I'd just add, in DCG, we saw strength in the cloud customers and over the course of the quarter, a weakening in the large enterprise purchases of server chips. So that -- the mix there was more to the cloud.
componenttext: And I'd just add, in DCG, we saw strength in the cloud customers and over the course of the quarter, a weakening in the large enterprise purchases of server chips. So that -- the mix there was more to the cloud.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Which had been strong in the first half.
componenttext: Which had been strong in the first half.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Which had been strong in the first half. Yes.
componenttext: Which had been strong in the first half. Yes.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up. Stacy, could you let us know what happened with units versus ASPs in PCs versus servers last quarter?
componenttext: And then as a follow-up. Stacy, could you let us know what happened with units versus ASPs in PCs versus servers last quarter?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's actually in the CFO commentary, JoAnne. But in general, we saw PC units up 1% versus the prior quarter and Data Center units were also up 1%. But this is a quarter-on-quarter compare.
componenttext: Yes, it's actually in the CFO commentary, JoAnne. But in general, we saw PC units up 1% versus the prior quarter and Data Center units were also up 1%. But this is a quarter-on-quarter compare.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sorry, and the ASPs?
componenttext: Sorry, and the ASPs?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: The PC ASPs were down 1% and the server ASPs were down 7% based on the mix kind of things that I've been talking about.
componenttext: The PC ASPs were down 1% and the server ASPs were down 7% based on the mix kind of things that I've been talking about.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Patrick Wang from Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Patrick Wang from Evercore Partners.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: First question. I want to see if you could go back to China. And Paul, maybe kind of recap some of the feedback you're hearing from those meetings you did have. Because it seems like the slowdown in China is really impacting global PC demand and weakness
componenttext: First question. I want to see if you could go back to China. And Paul, maybe kind of recap some of the feedback you're hearing from those meetings you did have. Because it seems like the slowdown in China is really impacting global PC demand and weakness out there. So just curious what the latest you're hearing.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, there is -- what I don't know is, how much of this in China is their own macroeconomic cycle slowing down. I mean, the GDP forecast for the year have come down -- for next year have come down. There's also a reasonable amount of anxiety around the c
componenttext: Well, there is -- what I don't know is, how much of this in China is their own macroeconomic cycle slowing down. I mean, the GDP forecast for the year have come down -- for next year have come down. There's also a reasonable amount of anxiety around the change in government. And that tends to put a little bit of nervousness into the system, and what I don't know is how much of that clarifies after they change because people -- it's not so much they don't know who's coming in, the issue is, what are the policies in terms of stimulus and taxation and so forth that have been pretty generous the last year or so -- a year or 2 rather in terms of stimulating domestic consumption. And the question is will those policies continue or not?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. Got you. That's hopeful. And I wanted to talk quickly about Data Center. The trend that we're seeing in ASPs right now of down 7% last quarter, I'm just kind of curious how you see that over the next couple of years here, because when we take
componenttext: Right. Okay. Got you. That's hopeful. And I wanted to talk quickly about Data Center. The trend that we're seeing in ASPs right now of down 7% last quarter, I'm just kind of curious how you see that over the next couple of years here, because when we take a look at your cloud segment forecasting pretty robust growth there, you talked about 50% of growth last quarter. Has that continued to really outstrip growth from your more traditional server customers? I mean, what is the -- what kind of impact does it do to your blended ASPs?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think the better comparison for the Data Center is year-on-year, which the ASP was up a bit, up 1%. The down a bit was really a big shift in the mix between the -- what would be normal enterprise growth and of slowing in the enterprise growth. In genera
componenttext: I think the better comparison for the Data Center is year-on-year, which the ASP was up a bit, up 1%. The down a bit was really a big shift in the mix between the -- what would be normal enterprise growth and of slowing in the enterprise growth. In general, for storage, for networking and I think for some aspects of the Internet Data Center, the mix is actually quite good. Sometimes two-way machines versus four-way machines, but they tend to -- a fairly high mix. And one of the fastest-growing elements of the business is High-performance computing, which buyers buy the top-of-the-line of our SKUs. So as those product lines get flushed out more and more, I really don't see the mix shifting away from where it's been the first half of this year. I see the current mix being a bit of an anomaly as a result of the softness of corporate Data Center server purchases.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Glen Yeung from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Glen Yeung from Citi.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Stacy, maybe a first question for you. As you sort of think about your capacity for 2013 and you're obviously taking action now, what kind of PC environment are you notionally targeting and maybe just an up or a down is sufficient, unless you want to be m
componenttext: Stacy, maybe a first question for you. As you sort of think about your capacity for 2013 and you're obviously taking action now, what kind of PC environment are you notionally targeting and maybe just an up or a down is sufficient, unless you want to be more specific?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to be less specific.
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to be less specific.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's one or the other.
componenttext: It's one or the other.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's one or the other, yes. It's either up or down or sideways. I'll hold off on triangulating on a capital forecast or on a unit growth until we get to next quarter. The CapEx number as I said is going to really be dependent on what we think unit growth
componenttext: It's one or the other, yes. It's either up or down or sideways. I'll hold off on triangulating on a capital forecast or on a unit growth until we get to next quarter. The CapEx number as I said is going to really be dependent on what we think unit growth is in '13 and '14. And right now, we're fighting through Q4. There's a lack of visibility on the current quarter. I want to have the 90 days to really think about what we want to put in place.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, fair enough. And then Paul, maybe this question for you. Notionally, we weren't expected to see -- when we have an operating transition like we're seeing a spark to PC demand, and yet we don't seem to be seeing that. And I wonder if you could just g
componenttext: Sure, fair enough. And then Paul, maybe this question for you. Notionally, we weren't expected to see -- when we have an operating transition like we're seeing a spark to PC demand, and yet we don't seem to be seeing that. And I wonder if you could just give us your thoughts as to why you think this time that's not happening.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't think we do. We know it's not happening yet. I'm very excited about this operating system as I said earlier, it brings touch into the mainstream for the first time. And we know that the last couple of years, tablets have changed the paradigm for p
componenttext: I don't think we do. We know it's not happening yet. I'm very excited about this operating system as I said earlier, it brings touch into the mainstream for the first time. And we know that the last couple of years, tablets have changed the paradigm for people to use computers. They like touch. They like to make their photos get larger with their fingers and everything else is good about that. So I think we haven't had a chance to really judge how the consumers will embrace this in mainstream PC space or not. I'm very optimistic as we've been playing with these things and we see the products being built and we take them out for testing to consumers, and we've now run tests on Windows 8 touch-enabled Ultrabooks in a number of the major cities around the world and across mobile demographics. The feedback is universally positive. So I think we're just too soon to tell. I mean the darn thing hasn't even launched yet. And we'll know a lot more about this 90 days from now.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our last question is from Sumit Dhanda from ISI.
componenttext: Our last question is from Sumit Dhanda from ISI.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First question for you, either Paul or Stacy. You noted that inventories are lean, and you expect half the normal seasonal growth in PCs, but you're dialing down that number.  Is the -- if the set up is lean from an inventory perspective, w
componenttext: Two questions. First question for you, either Paul or Stacy. You noted that inventories are lean, and you expect half the normal seasonal growth in PCs, but you're dialing down that number.  Is the -- if the set up is lean from an inventory perspective, why are your customers choosing to take down inventories even further or is that just a cushion you're building into your forecast for the fourth quarter?

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's just caution. We are seeing a very cautious environment. That I think it's a combination of what they're seeing from a macro standpoint and a slowing enterprise and an operating system transition and a weak consumer mature market segment. I t
componenttext: I think it's just caution. We are seeing a very cautious environment. That I think it's a combination of what they're seeing from a macro standpoint and a slowing enterprise and an operating system transition and a weak consumer mature market segment. I think all of that is just leading people to be cautious. Ultimately, I think leaner inventory levels are healthy, but that's what we're seeing right now.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: My second question was actually a follow-up on the server ASP stuff that was talked about earlier in the call. I think my question was, I think you talked about the fact that you have twice as many SKUs with Romley with a sort of the $1,000 mark from acro
componenttext: My second question was actually a follow-up on the server ASP stuff that was talked about earlier in the call. I think my question was, I think you talked about the fact that you have twice as many SKUs with Romley with a sort of the $1,000 mark from across the pricing perspective. Has the uptake on the higher SKUs stalled? And I guess sort of in line with this question, I was a little confused by why the cloud mix would be so much poorer versus the enterprise mix because I would've assumed that the uptake in cloud would be a richer mix and that would actually help your ASPs relative to the enterprise...

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: A lot of the cloud is two-way versus enterprise at four-way. At 50,000 feet, that's the simple answer.
componenttext: A lot of the cloud is two-way versus enterprise at four-way. At 50,000 feet, that's the simple answer.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the uptake for Romley of sort of above...
componenttext: Okay. And then the uptake for Romley of sort of above...

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Romley's been quite good.
componenttext: Romley's been quite good.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, everyone for joining us today. Patrick, please go ahead and wrap up the call for us.
componenttext: All right. Thanks, everyone for joining us today. Patrick, please go ahead and wrap up the call for us.

headline: Intel Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 16, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's program. This concludes the program. You may all disconnect.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's program. This concludes the program. You may all disconnect.
